post_text:
It's that Back-to-School time of year.
Welcome back, Bruins!

We have drive-through technology and school supply pick up events happening at the high school and middle school, and the start of in-person scheduled family orientation conferences happening for the lower grades. You can find info here: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/bruinsfwd

It's also the first day of Fall Food Distribution! Available in the BHHS parking lot drive-thru until 4 p.m. today. Free of charge for any youth ages 1-18 in the community. Find additional information here: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/menus/

post_text:
Hybrid and Online Only Students All Grades: Sept. 8-10 - Orientation activities (supplies, Chromebooks, drive-through or in-person teacher conferences, etc.)

Online-Only (All Grades): Online start date Friday, Sept. 11

Hybrid Details by Grade:
- Kindergarten - 3rd Grade: Hybrid start date Friday, Sept. 11 (half-day in-person in classrooms, and half-day distance learning)
- 4th - 5th Grade: Hybrid start date Friday, Sept. 11 (distance learning only), with plans to begin in-person half days the following week - Friday, Sept. 18.
- 6th - 8th Grade: Hybrid start date Friday, Sept. 11 (distance learning only), with plans to stay in distance learning for the first quarter and then re-evaluate
- 9th - 12th Grade: Hybrid start state Friday, Sept. 11 (distance learning only), with plans to stay in distance learning for the first quarter and then re-evaluate

More details at https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/news/article/1290229

post_text:
Reminder: 2020-21 School Supplies Provided for K-8

KSchool and Azalea Middle School students are NOT required to purchase supplies for the 2020-21 school year. All basic supplies have been funded by our district and purchased in bulk.

Unlike in recent years when Brookings-Harbor School District schools provided a list of recommended school supply purchases for grades K-8, this year the district will provide basic supplies for elementary and middle school students. These basic supplies include:

Paper
Pencils
Crayons
Colored Pencils
Rulers
Protractors
Glue
Paint
Glue Sticks
Calculators K-8
K-5 Classroom Snacks
Facial Tissues
Bleach Wipes

Find more back to school information at https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/bruinsfwd

post_text:
1 WEEK

The official start of the school year is one week away today! Information is being added daily to our school websites and 2020-21 Back to School Information hub at https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/bruinsfwd

Families of returning students, if you have not already done so, please complete your online registration forms ASAP! It is very important that you review and update the information that we have for your student on file. https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/register/

Read a recent update from Supt. David Marshall with an overview of what expect with instruction, and more details of new health and safety precautions: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/spotlightmessages/6817

New!: We learned yesterday that the state will extend the summer food program rules and funding through Dec. 31. This means BHSD will be able to provide meals for youth ages 1-18 free of charge through Dec. 31, 2020. In addition to serving any grade levels that are in-person on campus with deliveries to the classroom, we will also provide "grab and go" pick up meals every Monday, Wednesday, and Thursday from 7:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. in the BHHS parking lot. https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/menus/

Tech support reminder: As students at all levels engage in conferences or drive-up events next week from Sept. 8-10 to meet teachers, pick up supplies, and check out Chromebooks, we want to reshare the tech support contact information: If you need help with your district-issued device please contact our support team at techsupport@brookings.k12.or.us or call 541-412-1843. https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/news/article/1287072

shared_text:
Azalea Middle School
September 1 at 3:22 AM ·

Dear AMS Families,
Welcome to the school year 2020-2021. We are so grateful for your grace, support, and patience as we start the new school year. Our staff is dedicated to building student connections, creating meaningful work, and delivering a robust curriculum, no matter our distance.

This year staff and teachers are handing out the following student packs in new AMS swag bags on designated days listed below for our Meet and Greet Drive-Through:
Laptop Distribution (for those that did not keep one from last year)
School Supplies (binders, pens, pencils)
Student Schedules and AMS 2020 Planner

2020 Meet and Greet Drive-Through
9:00 - 11:00 AM and 2:00 - 4:00 PM
6th Grade: Tuesday, September 8, 2020
7th Grade: Wednesday, September 9, 2020
8th Grade: Thursday, September 10, 2020

Friday, September 11, 2020
All students will be required to virtually attend their assigned session (AM or PM) and all classes periods 1- 6. The Google Meet codes for these sessions will be in your student packs with your schedules.

Monday, September 14, 2020
Our students will begin comprehensive distance learning on Monday with an A Day schedule (see below). Teachers will be instructing online for each class period.

Respectfully,
Nicole Medrano, Principal, and Marco Thorson, Vice Principal

post_text:
Returning Student Online Registration: The time for registration for Brookings-Harbor School District students is here! Your family’s login information to your PowerSchool account was mailed to your mailing address on file on Wednesday, Aug. 12. You will be able to register your child for in-person instruction (when state metrics permit) and you will also have the option to register your child for our full online option, Brookings-Harbor K-12 Academy.

If you would like assistance with the online registration process, our three schools would all like to extend a helping hand. Please feel free to contact our front offices. Our office staff can help you over the phone as well as set up an individual appointment if you prefer.
* Kalmiopsis Elementary School (541) 469-7417
* Azalea Middle School (541) 469-7427
* Brookings Harbor High School (541) 469-2108

New and Transfer Student Online Registration: If you know someone new to the area, please let them know that they can call the school offices to get their registration accounts set up. We also have a drive-up K-12 information session available for new and transfer students.

New and Transfer Student Registration Help Drive-Thru Event:
* Date: Monday, August 17
* Times: 10:00 am-12:00 pm and 4:00 pm-6:00 pm
* Location: Kalmiopsis Elementary School, 650 Easy St. (Drive-through in front of Cafeteria/Gymnasium entrance)
* Process: Please come to the parking lot and stay in your car. Staff will meet you at your car and gather the needed initial registration information.
* For more information: Please call your school office and/or set up an appointment.

Need Help?
Step by Step: How to register online information available on the 2020-21 Registration webpage: www.brookings.k12.or.us/register/

post_text:
BHSD New and Transfer Student e-Registration Open!

Families of new and transfer students can complete an e-enrollment form for the 2020-21 academic year via a link on the Brookings-Harbor School District website at www.brookings.k12.or.us. Options are available for In-Person (Comprehensive Distance Learning Hybrid when allowed by State) or Brookings-Harbor K-12 Academy (Online Only).

The form collects basic contact information to complete an initial registration and must be completed for each new student in the family that intends to enroll.

Direct link to form: https://forms.gle/U2HoSir9U9tPxiiN9

Please note: Returning student registration is slated to open later this week (announcement TBA). At that time, login to the PowerSchool portal to complete the required forms for returning students.

post_text:
Today is the final distribution day of the 2020 Summer Reading program hosted by Chetco Community Public Library. Earlier this week, volunteers helped pack 650 activity bags that will be available at the library lobby from 1 to 6 pm today, as well as on the BOB Bus and at the Food Bank while supplies last.

Many thanks to the sponsors and donors who helped make this program happen for our local youth and children: AllCare Health, Advanced Health, Brookings Harbor Education Foundation, Kasper - Kids After School Program of Education and Recreation, Grocery Outlet, McDonald's, Fred Meyer, and Dairy Queen Grill & Chill.

For a complete list of resources and help lines visit: https://govstatus.egov.com/or-dhs-not-alone

post_text: Information for families receiving SNAP food benefits.
shared_text:
Brookings Harbor Community Helpers Emergency Food Bank
July 27 at 2:30 PM ·

Good Morning everyone! Based on the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and the extension of Oregon's emergency declaration, additional SNAP benefits have been approved for households currently receiving SNAP benefits up to the maximum amount allowed the same as May and June 2020. No notices will go out to those who qualify. These emergency SNAP allotments should be on your SNAP card now for July August 11th is the date for next months distribution. Please contact us or your local DHS office for more information. Please share with those who receive SNAP benefits. Thank you!

post_text:
On Tuesday, Oregon Governor Kate Brown announced a new set of metrics that will determine when schools can safely reopen their buildings to return to in-person learning.

The key metrics are based on BOTH state-level infection and positive test rates as well as local county-level infection and positive test rates. The target metrics need to be achieved for three consecutive weeks state-wide AND within Curry County.

At the local level, Curry County is near the range of metrics to allow for us to open in-person, however, the state-level rates are not at this point in time. Learn more about what this means on our Fall Planning webpage: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/2020fallplanning

---
At this time, BHSD is continuing its planning process for in-person instruction as well as distance education and online learning, although it more likely now that school will start with distance and online only. As new information and updates become available, we will continue to share with our school families. All current families should be receiving a call from their school office this week. If you miss your call or you are new or returning to the district this fall we encourage you to call the school district or specific school office to share your learning path preference and accommodation needs for fall.
text:

The key metrics are based on BOTH state-level infection and positive test rates as well as local county-level infection and positive test rates. The target metrics need to be achieved for three consecutive weeks state-wide AND within Curry County.

At the local level, Curry County is near the range of metrics to allow for us to open in-person, however, the state-level rates are not at this point in time. Learn more about what this means on our Fall Planning webpage: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/2020fallplanning

---
At this time, BHSD is continuing its planning process for in-person instruction as well as distance education and online learning, although it more likely now that school will start with distance and online only. As new information and updates become available, we will continue to share with our school families. All current families should be receiving a call from their school office this week. If you miss your call or you are new or returning to the district this fall we encourage you to call the school district or specific school office to share your learning path preference and accommodation needs for fall.

post_text:
Take the BHSD Fall Planning Survey! - Open Until 5 p.m. Friday, July 10: https://forms.gle/GwqdBLD3CLttZB467

Message from Supt. David Marshall:

[June 26, 2020] Greetings Brookings-Harbor School District Families,

I am looking forward to continuing to get to know the Brookings-Harbor community and would like to thank the people I’ve met so far for their warm welcome. I want to let community members know that I have an open-door policy and am happy to visit with and listen to your thoughts and concerns.

I recognize that one of the pressing topics on many people’s minds is what will the start of school look like this fall.

Our focus is on the safety of our students and staff as we develop our plans to reopen the schools in the fall. The Oregon Department of Education put out this guidance that was developed in collaboration with the Oregon Health Authority and the Governor’s office. If you have the opportunity, I encourage you to have a look at this document. We will be using it to guide our planning efforts this summer. (Link to document: https://www.oregon.gov/ode/students-and-family/healthsafety/Pages/Planning-for-the-2020-21-School-Year.aspx)

Your input is an important part of the planning process and it would be very helpful if you would take a few minutes to respond to this survey that will be used to inform the planning process. (Link to survey: https://forms.gle/GwqdBLD3CLttZB467) You are also welcome to email me directly or set up an appointment to come in and visit.

As we determine our next steps, we will post them on an FAQ page on our web site and share the information via newsletters and other channels.

A few important highlights of the guidance (though this is far from all of it!):

- Physical distancing of up to 6 ft or 35 square feet per student in spaces is required. (We will need to calculate what this means for our class sizes and the number of students we can have in a building at one time.)
- We will need to stagger where students enter and exit the building and keep track of who’s coming in and out.
Playgrounds will be open to students during the school day (limited groups at a time) and sanitized between use.
- We will need to keep student groups together (such as classes) to the extent possible.
- We will need to work with our health department in the event of a case or an outbreak.

Please know that, throughout our planning, we will always keep in mind that our schools must continue to be warm, caring communities, even with these new rules.

Thank you for our continued patience and grace as we work through this together with our students’ best interests in our hearts.

Respectfully,
David Marshall, Superintendent

------
[26 de junio de 2020] - Saludos Familias del Distrito Escolar de Brookings-Harbor,

Espero seguir conociendo a la comunidad de Brookings-Harbor y me gustaría agradecer a las personas que he conocido hasta ahora por su linda bienvenida. Quiero informar a los miembros de la comunidad que tengo una tactica de puertas abiertas y estoy feliz de visitar y escuchar sus pensamientos y preocupaciones.

Reconozco que uno de los temas apremiantes en la mente de muchas personas es cómo será el comienzo de la escuela este otoño.

Nuestro enfoque es la seguridad de nuestros estudiantes y personal mientras desarrollamos nuestros planes para reabrir la escuela en el otoño. El Departamento de Educación de Oregon publicó hizo esta guía que fue desarrollada en colaboración con la Autoridad de Salud de Oregon y la oficina del Gobernador. Si tienes la oportunidad, te animo a que leas este documento. Lo usaremos para guiar nuestros esfuerzos de planificación este verano.

Su contribución es una parte importante del proceso de planificación y sería muy útil si toma unos minutos para responder a esta breve encuesta que se utilizará para informar el proceso de planificación. (enlace de la encuesta) También puede enviarme un correo electrónico directamente o programar una cita para vernos en persona.

A medida que determinamos nuestros próximos pasos, los publicaremos en una página de preguntas frecuentes en nuestro sitio web y compartiremos la información a través de boletines y otros canales.

Algunos puntos destacados importantes de la guía (¡aunque esto está lejos de ser todo!):
- Se requiere un distanciamiento físico de hasta 6 pies o 35 pies cuadrados por estudiante en un espacio. (Tendremos que calcular qué significa esto para el tamaño de nuestras clases y la cantidad de estudiantes que podemos tener en un edificio al mismo tiempo).
- Tendremos que tambalearnos por donde los estudiantes entran y salen del edificio y realizar un seguimiento de quién entra y sale. .
- Los patios de juego estarán abiertos a los estudiantes durante el día escolar (grupos limitados a la vez) y desinfectados entre usos.
- Tendremos que mantener a los grupos de estudiantes juntos (como las clases) en la medida de lo posible.
- Tendremos que trabajar con nuestro departamento de salud en caso de un caso o un brote.

Tenga en cuenta que, a lo largo de nuestra planificación, siempre tendremos en cuenta que nuestras escuelas deben seguir siendo comunidades cálidas y afectuosas, incluso con estas nuevas reglas.

Gracias por su paciencia y gracia mientras trabajamos en esto juntos con el mejor interés de nuestros estudiantes en nuestros corazones.

Respetuosamente,
David Marshall, Superintendente

Espero seguir conociendo a la comunidad de Brookings-Harbor y me gustaría agradecer a las personas que he conocido hasta ahora por su linda bienvenida. Quiero informar a los miembros de la comunidad que tengo una tactica de puertas abiertas y estoy feliz de visitar y escuchar sus pensamientos y preocupaciones.

Reconozco que uno de los temas apremiantes en la mente de muchas personas es cómo será el comienzo de la escuela este otoño.

Nuestro enfoque es la seguridad de nuestros estudiantes y personal mientras desarrollamos nuestros planes para reabrir la escuela en el otoño. El Departamento de Educación de Oregon publicó hizo esta guía que fue desarrollada en colaboración con la Autoridad de Salud de Oregon y la oficina del Gobernador. Si tienes la oportunidad, te animo a que leas este documento. Lo usaremos para guiar nuestros esfuerzos de planificación este verano.

Su contribución es una parte importante del proceso de planificación y sería muy útil si toma unos minutos para responder a esta breve encuesta que se utilizará para informar el proceso de planificación. (enlace de la encuesta) También puede enviarme un correo electrónico directamente o programar una cita para vernos en persona.

A medida que determinamos nuestros próximos pasos, los publicaremos en una página de preguntas frecuentes en nuestro sitio web y compartiremos la información a través de boletines y otros canales.

Algunos puntos destacados importantes de la guía (¡aunque esto está lejos de ser todo!):
- Se requiere un distanciamiento físico de hasta 6 pies o 35 pies cuadrados por estudiante en un espacio. (Tendremos que calcular qué significa esto para el tamaño de nuestras clases y la cantidad de estudiantes que podemos tener en un edificio al mismo tiempo).
- Tendremos que tambalearnos por donde los estudiantes entran y salen del edificio y realizar un seguimiento de quién entra y sale. .
- Los patios de juego estarán abiertos a los estudiantes durante el día escolar (grupos limitados a la vez) y desinfectados entre usos.
- Tendremos que mantener a los grupos de estudiantes juntos (como las clases) en la medida de lo posible.
- Tendremos que trabajar con nuestro departamento de salud en caso de un caso o un brote.

Tenga en cuenta que, a lo largo de nuestra planificación, siempre tendremos en cuenta que nuestras escuelas deben seguir siendo comunidades cálidas y afectuosas, incluso con estas nuevas reglas.

Gracias por su paciencia y gracia mientras trabajamos en esto juntos con el mejor interés de nuestros estudiantes en nuestros corazones.

Respetuosamente,
David Marshall, Superintendente

post_text:
The Class of 2020 experienced a senior year like no other, but there is so much to celebrate about these bright young Bruins.

101 graduates
1,265 college credits earned
84 students taking college classes
6 seniors graduating with an honors diploma
10 seniors graduating with academic excellence certificates
42% post-secondary enrollment (2 and 4-year colleges)
$130,000 in scholarships awarded
41 students received scholarships
2 Ivy League offers
20 State Playoffs in 4 years
5 Military appointments
1,541 Community Service Hours Performed by Students

Incredible!

Find the gradution video recap, photo galleries, list of graduates, list of honors, list of scholarships, and more on our Graduation Information page. https://bhhs.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/graduation

post_text:
Sharing for community partners of our Foster Child Student Services team:

--
Have you ever wondered what it takes to be a foster parent? Are you interested in hearing experienced foster parents share about the joys and heartbreaks of foster care in a no-pressure environment?

Explore Fostering events normally take place at a local coffee shop near you. We have the opportunity to listen to a panel of foster parents share about their experiences. We recognize that in this current situation around COVID-19 that is not possible, however, we feel it’s important to continue to provide a space for you to get your questions answered.

Grab a drink or cup of coffee and join us online. We look forward to meeting you on the call!

We hope you can join us on June 11th from 7:00-8:30 pm for this! Thank you for your interest in learning more about fostering in Curry or Coos County.

For Curry and Coos families interested in learning more about welcoming a child into their home through foster care:
REGISTER in advance for this meeting: https://everychildoregon.org/events/

After registering, you will receive a confirmation email containing the password to join the Zoom meeting.

post_text:
Reminder: You can apply for free or reduced-price lunches via this link on our website: https://www.mymealtime.com/Apps/SignIn.aspx?ReturnUrl=%2fapps

---
Information on Pandemic EBT funds from State of Oregon

If your children normally get free or reduced-price school meals, you’re eligible to get extra grocery money. It’s a new program called Pandemic-EBT (P-EBT).
For each month that school is closed and you are eligible, you will get $5.70 per day for each of your children in a K-12 school, school-based preschool, or school-based Headstart that normally participate in the National School Lunch Program. AND you can still get “grab and go” meals from school during the pandemic.
Immigration status does not matter for Pandemic EBT. Pandemic EBT will not count in a public charge test.
Here are the ways your family can receive the Pandemic EBT benefit:

1. Already get SNAP? The extra money will be loaded on your Oregon Trail EBT card automatically.

2. Don’t have SNAP, but already qualify for free or reduced school meals? A new EBT card will be automatically mailed to you with instructions. If your whole school gets free meals (such as Kalmiopsis Elementary, which is a “Provision 2 School” with free breakfast and lunch), you will qualify too. Even though Pandemic EBT uses the same type of card as SNAP, Pandemic EBT is NOT SNAP benefits and is not considered in a public charge test.

3. Never received SNAP or free and reduced-price school meals before? A simple way to access the P-EBT benefit is by applying for free school meals here: https://www.mymealtime.com/Apps/SignIn.aspx?ReturnUrl=%2fapps

4. Receiving SNAP benefits can also qualify you, here's how to apply https://govstatus.egov.com/or-dhs-benefits. You will automatically be given Pandemic EBT benefits starting the month you’re approved for either free school meals or SNAP.

To find out more information, you can visit oregonhunger.org/covid-19 or call 2-1-1. We can also field questions at Brookings-Harbor School District, please email Food Service Director Cindy Badger at cindyba@brookings.k12.or.us.

For more food resources, please visit http://needfood.oregon.gov/. For more information on our school programs, see www.brookings.k12.or.us.

post_text:
Do you need help paying your electric bill?

If you need help paying your electric bill, check out the Oregon Energy Fund. It provides funds for energy assistance to more than 30 partner agencies and nonprofits in Oregon. Visit the website and enter your county or zip code to find out who has energy assistance in your area and how to contact them. (Note that the office does not provide direct assistance but connects people in need with available local resources.)

http://www.oregonenergyfund.org/energy-assistance/

In our region, Oregon Coast Community Action (ORCCA) also has a program that you can contact for more information about 541-469-3155 or 541-435-7080 or energy@orcca.us. https://www.orcca.us/covid-19-resources

post_text:
The Department of Human Services (DHS) and the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) announced today that Oregon families with children who are eligible for free or reduced-price school meals will get cash benefits for the meals they would have received at school even if they have been accessing meals from schools during the closure.

The USDA Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) authorized DHS to provide Oregon P-EBT Pandemic School Meal Replacement Benefits to more than 351,000 students receiving free or reduced-price school meals in Oregon, including almost 147,000 students already receiving Nutrition Assistance. Households will receive benefits equivalent to one free
lunch and one free breakfast for each eligible child – $5.70 per normal school day for the months of March, April, May and June.
“Together, DHS and ODE are working to ensure no child in Oregon goes hungry during the COVID-19 pandemic,” said Dan Haun, DHS Self-Sufficiency Programs Director. “This resource is the result of our strong collaboration and will provide additional support for child nutrition and expand families’ options for healthy food.”

https://www.ode.state.or.us/apps/FRLApp/Default

ODE.STATE.OR.US
Home - Free and Reduced Lunch
text:
The Department of Human Services (DHS) and the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) announced today that Oregon families with children who are eligible for free or reduced-price school meals will get cash benefits for the meals they would have received at school even if they have been accessing meals from schools during the closure.

The USDA Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) authorized DHS to provide Oregon P-EBT Pandemic School Meal Replacement Benefits to more than 351,000 students receiving free or reduced-price school meals in Oregon, including almost 147,000 students already receiving Nutrition Assistance. Households will receive benefits equivalent to one free
lunch and one free breakfast for each eligible child – $5.70 per normal school day for the months of March, April, May and June.
“Together, DHS and ODE are working to ensure no child in Oregon goes hungry during the COVID-19 pandemic,” said Dan Haun, DHS Self-Sufficiency Programs Director. “This resource is the result of our strong collaboration and will provide additional support for child nutrition and expand families’ options for healthy food.”

https://www.ode.state.or.us/apps/FRLApp/Default

Home - Free and Reduced Lunch

post_text: Reminder: If you need delivery of essential items such as food or prescription medications, there is a local volunteer delivery service coordinated by Coastline Neighbors. See flyers for details.
shared_text:
Brookings-Harbor School District 17C
April 8 at 9:48 AM ·

The Curry Essential Needs Collaborative is organizing a community-wide plan between different agencies to come together to serve the elderly, disabled, medically fragile, post-partum mothers and low-resource people in our community during the Covid-19 Stay-at-home order.

Coastline Neighbors will serve as the lead organization to coordinate and implement this effort. They will collaborate with other community agencies and volunteers as needed to help ensure that food and medicine are delivered for free to people’s homes.

Pharmaceuticals and durable medical equipment that cannot be delivered by the retail pharmacy or transferred to a mail-order pharmacy will be obtained by volunteers, staff or contracted transportation services.

If you are a member of the community and wish to provide public comment, please email your comments to dedec@brookings.k12.or.us 24 hours ahead of the meeting and your comments will be part of the public record.

The direct link to the livestream will be https://youtu.be/BdLwjs6T4pk

BHSD families,

Due to high demand, we are projected to run out of today’s food distribution supplies before closing.

We expect today’s Tuesday, April 7, event will end early at 6 p.m., rather than the advertised 8 p.m. regular closure time.

We regret any inconvenience caused by this early closure. If your family missed out and you would like to notify the school district, please contact the District Office.

We are working with our foodservice suppliers to scale up future distribution days as we are able.

~Supt. Chris Eberhardt

post_text:
Yesterday (April 1) Brookings-Harbor school principals met virtually with their teaching and support teams as they prepare to serve students during the extended closure.

Every student in our district will receive a phone call from one of their teachers by the end-of-day Friday, April 3.

The goal of this phone call is to reconnect with your student and prepare for a distance learning model to start in the coming weeks.

You will also be asked a few questions about the technology you have available in your home. These questions will help us develop our technology support plan for families that may need some assistance or a device on loan.

If you have not received a phone call by the end of the day Friday, please contact your student’s principal via their school email. Email is the best way to reach your principal at this time because our offices are closed to visitors and most staff are working off-site.

We look forward to working with your family, as we develop educational plans for ALL our Brookings-Harbor students.

Chris Eberhardt, Superintendent

Here is where you can find our emails: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/news/article/1202516

post_text:
Here's what will be in Friday's food bags, which are built to sustain up to two kids in a household for four days:

Hamburger
Tots
Peanut butter
Honey
Tortillas
Lunchmeat
Cereal
Breakfast bar
Shredded cheese
Mayo
Mustard
Bagged vegetables
Milk
Fruit cup
Bread/bun
Fresh fruit
juice
(and crackers while supplies last).

On Tuesday, 521 youth ages 1-18 in our community received food. Thank you to community partner Brookings Harbor Community Helpers Emergency Food Bank for snack pack items that are included with cold and fresh items from the district.

Food pick-up to feed young people in your household is available from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. Tuesdays and Fridays at the Brookings-Harbor High School cafeteria (625 Pioneer Road, Brookings, OR 97415), during the extended closure of Oregon schools (schools closed March 16-April 28). There is a drive-up/walk-up line marked with cones in the parking lot. Thank you for your cooperation to help us maintain social distance guidelines. Youth in your household do not have to be enrolled in BHSD to receive food.

Find all updates at www.brookings.k12.or.us

shared_text:
Curry Community Health
March 30 at 1:22 PM ·

During this current health crisis, Mental Health and Behavioral Health services are still available through Curry Community Health. We have moved most of our services to online platforms and telephone delivery to continue to provide needed services while ensuring safety for all of our community.

Please note that our office hours have changed during this time. The Gold Beach clinic is open Monday, Wednesday and Friday, and the Port Orford clinic is closed. You can however, attend your appointments from home via telehealth, or telephone anyday your provider is available.

If you or a loved one need services please do not hesitate to call our office at 541-813-2535 for appointment information and telehealth options. If you are in crisis, our 24-hour crisis line at 877-519-9322 is also always available.

Thank you to all on our school staff and in our community who helped launch the initial week of food distribution (March 16-20) to provide important nutrition to young people in our community impacted by the sudden "extended spring break" closure of schools caused by COVID-19/Coronavirus concerns across the state and world, and mandated by Gov. Kate Brown.

We have some updates on how these events will operate moving forward ...

Brookings-Harbor School District will resume food distribution events starting Tuesday, March 31. Food pick up to feed young people in your household ages 1-18 will be available from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. Tuesdays and Fridays (March 31, April 3, April 7, April 10, April 14, April 17, April 21, and April 24) at the Brookings-Harbor High School cafeteria (625 Pioneer Road, Brookings, OR 97415), during the extended closure of Oregon schools (schools closed March 16-April 28). During these events, we are taking extra food handling and crowd control precautions.

There will not be food distribution during the week of March 23-27 (original Oregon Spring Break). During this week, the Brookings-Harbor Community Helpers Emergency Food Bank (539 Hemlock St, Brookings, OR 97415) will provide snack packs for pick-up daily from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Monday to Friday. Please continue to check the Brookings-Harbor School District website for information and updates: www.brookings.k12.or.us.

post_text:
Una extensión de mandato de cerrar las escuelas
[Actualización BHSD #8 - 6 p.m. Martes, 17 de marzo de 2020]

Queridas Familias del Distrito Escolar Brookings-Harbor,

La gobernadora de Oregón, Kate Brown, ha anunciado una extensión de su mandato de cerrar las escuelas de Oregón para ayudar a prevenir la propagación de COVID-19 (coronavirus). Las nuevas órdenes del gobernador significan que las escuelas permanecerán cerradas hasta el 28 de abril de 2020.

Sabemos que este es un momento difícil y que la cerrada de nuestras escuelas es un desafío. Por favor, sepa que estamos haciendo todo lo posible para planificar el regreso potencial de nuestros estudiantes y estamos buscando orientación adicional del Departamento de Educación de Oregón durante esta cerrada extendida.

Lo que sí sabemos en este momento:

Continuaremos con una distribución de alimentos en caja o embolsados del distrito escolar y distribuiremos "paquetes de bocadillos" del banco de alimentos local. Consulte nuestro sitio web para obtener información sobre fechas y horas.
Nuestras instalaciones permanecerán cerradas a los estudiantes y a la mayoría del personal durante la cerrada extendida.
Mientras nuestros estudiantes están fuera de la escuela, por favor ayúdelos a entender la importancia de esta emergencia nacional de salud fomentando el distanciamiento social, la buena higiene de las manos, evitando a las personas enfermas y cubriendo sus tos y estornudos. Las reuniones de más de 10 personas no son recomendadas por el gobierno de los Estados Unidos en este momento.

Agradecemos su comprensión mientras navegamos por esta situación en constante cambio. Estamos compilando recursos en nuestro sitio web para que pueda acceder rápidamente a la información. Puede acceder a nuestra página de información y recursos de BHSD COVID-19 en www.brookings.k12.or.us.

Estaré en contacto con más información tan pronto como tengamos un plan para navegar por esta cerrada extendida. Por favor, haga lo que pueda para ayudar a prevenir la propagación de este virus.

Gracias,

Chris Eberhardt, Superintendente
Distrito Escolar Brookings-Harbor

¿Continuarán los programas de alimentos del distrito escolar durante la cerrada?

Para la semana del 16 al 12 de marzo: en un esfuerzo de continuar los servicios nutricionales para nuestros estudiantes durante la cerrada de emergencia, el Distrito Escolar de Brookings-Harbor entregará cajas de comida el martes 17 de marzo y el viernes 20 de marzo. Las cajas estarán disponibles en su parada de autobús durante lo que sería la hora normal de recogida en la ruta de la mañana. Cualquier estudiante que actualmente utiliza el programa de alimentación escolar es elegible para recibir una caja al dar su nombre. Los padres / tutores / familiares pueden recoger en nombre de los niños. Además, las cajas estarán disponibles para recoger fuera de la cafetería de la escuela secundaria el martes y Viernes de 7:00 a.m. a 10:00 a.m. El nombre del estudiante serán necesarios para ser recogidos en el sitio de la cafetería BHHS.

post_text:
Dear Brookings-Harbor School District Families,

Oregon Governor Kate Brown has announced an extension to her mandate to close Oregon schools to help prevent the spread of COVID-19 (coronavirus). The governor’s new orders mean that schools will be closed until April 28, 2020.

We know this is a trying time and that the closure of our schools is a challenge. Please know we are doing all we can to plan for our students’ potential return and are looking for additional guidance from the Oregon Department of Education during this extended closure.

What we do know right now:

- We will continue a food distribution of boxed or bagged food from the school district and distribute “snack packs” from the local food bank. See our website for information on dates and times.

- Our facilities will remain closed to students and most staff during the extended closure

While our students are away from school, please help them understand the importance of this national health emergency by encouraging social distancing, good hand hygiene, avoiding people who are sick, and covering their coughs and sneezes. Gatherings of more than 10 people are not recommended by the U.S. government at this time.

We appreciate your understanding as we navigate this constantly-changing situation. We are compiling resources on our website so you can quickly access information. You can access our BHSD COVID-19 information and resources page at www.brookings.k12.or.us.

I will be in touch with more information as soon as we have a plan to navigate this extended closure. Please do what you can to help prevent the spread of this virus.

Thank you,

Chris Eberhardt, Superintendent
Brookings-Harbor School District
[BHSD Update #8 - 6 p.m. Tuesday, March 17, 2020]

https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1399758&type=d&pREC_ID=1850000

post_text:
BHSD Nutrition Services Update
[BHSD Update #6 03/13/2020]

In an effort to continue nutritional services for our students during the emergency closure, the Brookings-Harbor School District will be delivering food boxes on Tuesday, March 17th and Friday, March 20th. The boxes will be available at your bus stop during what would be the normal morning route pick up time. Any student that currently utilizes the school food program is eligible to receive a box by supplying either their name or their lunch code.

In addition, boxes will be available for pick up at the high school cafeteria on Tuesday and Friday from 7:00 am to 10:00 am.

Notification from Snack Pack Program of
Brookings Harbor Community Helpers Emergency Food Bank:

The Brookings Harbor Food Bank will be distributing snack packs March 16 through April 30th or until further notice for Children 1-17 years of age. The snack packs will be available for pick up at the Food Bank Monday through Friday 10 am to 1 pm, 539 Hemlock Street. Please Contact Food Bank Director Pamela Winebarger, if you have any questions 541-469-6988.

Please continue to check the district website for more information and updates. https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/covid19updates/ (https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1399758&type=d&pREC_ID=1850000)

post_text:
COVID 19 Update - BHSD Cancelations from 3/12/20 to 4/8/20

We know it will be a big disappointment to many of our young people and to the community at large, but we are saddened to inform you that our extra-curricular activities will be canceled for the next four weeks. These activities include athletics competitions, assemblies, community events, off-campus field trips, professional development meetings, and more.

We are committed to the best health outcomes for the whole community and are following the new guidance for the COVID-19 outbreak prevention announced by the State.

Please check BHSD’s activities cancelation list frequently for updates. If you have questions about an event on the list or one that is not listed, please contact your school office or email info@brookings.k12.or.us.

~ Chris Eberhardt, Superintendent

Canceled events
- All high school and middle school athletics competitions until April 8, 2020.
- All community uses of facilities (including adult, high school and youth activities). The only allowed users will be practice sessions for in-season, OSAA-sanctioned, and school-sponsored teams.
- BHHS Spring Parent Athletic Meeting, March 12, BHHS Gym.
- BHHS Site Council, March 12, BHHS Library.
- SeaBreeze Choir Field Trip, March 13-14, Humboldt State University.
- StemEco Field Trip, March 13, Gold Beach. Will be rescheduled.
- Kalmiopsis Ocean World Field Trip, 2nd Grade, March 13 & 18, Crescent City.
- FIRST Robotics Field Trip, March 13-15, Wilsonville.
- Azalea Middle School Band & Orchestra Concert, March 17, AMS Cafeteria.
- Azalea Middle School Choir Concert, March 18, AMS Music Room.
- BHHS Talent Show, March 18, BHHS Auditorium.
Conversation Project Assembly for Azalea Students, March 19, AMS Gym.
- Athletic Code of Conduct Committee Meeting, March 19, BHHS Library.
- Student of the Month Assembly, March 20, for Kalmiopsis Elementary students.
- Winterguard Competition, March 20-22, Portland.
- FIRST Robotics Competition, March 26-28, Salem-Keizer.
- French Club Field Trip, April 3-5, Portland. Will reschedule.

This list will be updated as new information is available.

A COVID-19/Coronavirus resource and information page is now available on our website at https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/. Our students' health and safety is our number one concern and we are monitoring the situation closely and will keep you informed on how this issue may impact our school district.

-

Help stop the spread of germs to prevent respiratory diseases like COVID-19:

- Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
- Cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
- Avoid touching you eyes, nose, and mouth.
- Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.
- Stay home when you are sick, except to get medical care.
- Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.

~
Details: With the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) from Brookings Harbor Education Association (BHEA) and with School Board approval, we are moving forward with a Professional Development day on Friday, March 6, 2020. This is a change to the academic calendar.

Here is our schedule for teachers and staff on March 6:

8:00 - 8:45 am Check in and Social Gathering: High School Cafeteria
9:00 am - 12:30 pm Poverty Simulation Training for All Staff: High School Gym
12:30 - 1:15 pm Lunch on your Own
1:15 - 2:00 pm Breakout Session One: Locations to be determined
2:15 - 3:00 pm Breakout Session Two: Locations to be determined
3:00 - 3:30 pm Ice Cream Social: High School Cafeteria

Click on this link, Rethink Poverty, if you would like to see a video of what the Poverty Simulation experience is like: https://www.dreamcenterpeoria.org/rethinkpoverty

~
Details: With the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) from Brookings Harbor Education Association (BHEA) and with School Board approval, we are moving forward with a Professional Development day on Friday, March 6, 2020. This is a change to the academic calendar.

Here is our schedule for teachers and staff on March 6:

8:00 - 8:45 am Check in and Social Gathering: High School Cafeteria
9:00 am - 12:30 pm Poverty Simulation Training for All Staff: High School Gym
12:30 - 1:15 pm Lunch on your Own
1:15 - 2:00 pm Breakout Session One: Locations to be determined
2:15 - 3:00 pm Breakout Session Two: Locations to be determined
3:00 - 3:30 pm Ice Cream Social: High School Cafeteria

Click on this link, Rethink Poverty, if you would like to see a video of what the Poverty Simulation experience is like: https://www.dreamcenterpeoria.org/rethinkpoverty

post_text:
Update: Navigating the Student Success Act road map

The Brookings-Harbor School District Board of Directors -- in partnership with the District Leadership Team -- has established the priorities of student success, high-quality staff, and increasing positive relationships.

As a district, we are working on aligning our Continuous Improvement Plan with these district priorities. Through this process and the submission of our plan to the state, we expect to receive an estimated $1.2 million through the Student Success Act/Student Investment Account process for the coming 2020-2021 budget cycle.

We will continue to monitor progress towards the district’s priorities through superintendent reports during our monthly regular board meetings, including tonight's meeting at 5 p.m. Wednesday, Jan. 15, in the Kalmiopsis Elementary School Library.

For more information, see www.brookings.k12.or.us and visit our Student Success Act, School Board, and Data & Reports sections, or check out the ODE's Student Success Act information page at https://www.oregon.gov/ode/StudentSuccess/Pages/default.aspx.

post_text: Thank you Wild Rivers Community Foundation and donors for the generous Holiday Partnership mini-grant for the Brookings-Harbor High School Youth Transition Program (YTP) to create canned cranberries for donation to local food programs, and funds to create a Thanksgiving tamale feast!
shared_text:
Wild Rivers Community Foundation
December 5, 2019 at 7:59 PM ·

THE SEASON FOR GIVING!

What a wonderful night of heartfelt stories and the power of giving!

Wild Rivers Community Foundation awarded $22,000 in grants Wednesday to 29 nonprofit organizations, agencies and churches that provide thousands of children and adults in Curry and Del Norte counties with much-needed food, clothing, gifts, companionship and other services.

“This is a celebration of all of you and the hope you give those in our communities who really need it,” said WRCF Director Gina Zottola. More than 60 people gathered for the Holiday Partnership ceremony at Howenquet Hall in Smith River.

This is the twelfth year that WRCF has awarded holiday grants ranging from $250 to $2,000. The grants — funded by donations from family trusts, foundations, businesses and individuals — support programs that provide children with winter coats or Christmas presents, and holiday food for hungry families. The grants are also used for warm clothes for struggling veterans and the homeless, and support services for abused or neglected children.

“We are so amazed by the generosity of the community and happy to be a part of it,” said Kelly Schellong, of Bicoastal Media, which hosts the annual Coats for Kids campaign. “Last year, we used this money to provide coats to 1,407 kids in Curry and Del Norte counties.”

Roger Gilbert, of the Brookings Presbyterian Church, said the grant will be used to cover some of the costs associated with providing a free Thanksgiving meal to needy residents via the Community Kitchen program operated by five churches in Brookings. “It’s all about eliminating hunger in our community, and on Thanksgiving we were able to provide more than 100 hot meals."

Daphne Cortese, of the new nonprofit Del Norte Mission Possible, will use the money to provide essential supplies to homeless people. “I’m going to let them know that this money is from the community, to let them know that they have value. They are valued. This is going to do more than buy socks, it’s going to build bridges.”

Zottola thanked WRCF’s donors who provide the grant funding. “Tonight wouldn’t be possible — we wouldn’t have this pool of resources — if not for our community partners. Last year, the grants blessed the lives of more than 7,000 people. It’s proof that, collectively, we can move the needle. We can affect change in our communities.”

This year’s donors include the Brattain Family Trust; the Dale & Jo Ann Thomas Charitable Fund; the John G. Atkins Foundation; Pacific Power; Patricia D. & William B. Smullin Foundation; St. Joseph’s Health System Humboldt; South Fork/Big Flat Endowment Fund; R. Baird & Jane Rumiano Family Fund; Gordon Elwood Foundation, The California Endowment and WRCF.

post_text:
Week of Thankfulness - Day 3

Many thanks to Dollar General Literacy Foundation for awarding Brookings-Harbor School District a Dollar General Youth Literacy Grant for 2019 of $1000. These DG grants were announced in September and provide $2.8 million to organizations across 44 states to support youth literacy initiatives during the 2019-2020 academic year. We are one of only 6 organizations from Oregon to receive this competitive nationwide grant.

The funds will be used to purchase copies of the illustrated children’s book “30 Minutes Over Oregon” for all students in the 5th grade as part of a local history project culminating with events with community members, local historians, and high school history and social studies classes.

An Orbis Pictus Honor Book for Outstanding Nonfiction 2019, “30 Minutes Over Oregon” is a story of war and reconciliation. It tells the story of Japanese pilot Nobuo Fujita who dropped bombs in the woods outside Brookings during WW2, the events that brought him back to visit twenty years later, and the enduring connection to Brookings.

We are excited to be in talks with author Marc Tyler Nobleman and illustrator Melissa Iwai who created “30 Minutes Over Oregon” for possible school and community visits this spring. The Chetco Community Public Library — which is the home of Nobuo Fujita’s family samurai sword — and the Chetco Historical Society Museum are partners in this effort to engage students in local history.

If you or your organization is interested in learning more, please contact Brookings-Harbor High School social studies teacher Kelly Garvin at kellyg@brookings.k12.or.us or District Librarian Patty Clark at patriciac@brookings.k12.or.us.

post_text:
Week of Thankfulness - Day 2

We are grateful for all those who volunteer to help lead our school system. This includes our elected volunteer School Board of Directors, budget committee members, school SITE Council members, and more. Thank you for your time, collaborative efforts, and support of our schools.

We currently are seeking a budget committee member, and community members to take part in our Superintendent Search committee and District Leadership Team (DLT). Read on for details ...

—
Budget Committee - Open until filled!

The Brookings-Harbor School Board is seeking to fill one remaining vacancy on the Budget Committee. The application is now open for community members wishing to serve a three-year term on the committee. The one-page application is available as a PDF or Word document and is due to the School District office at 564 Fern Ave., Brookings, OR 97415 or via email attachment to Dede Corpening at dedec@brookings.k12.or.us. http://www.brookings.k12.or.us/budget/

—
Seeking Superintendent Search Committee Members

The Brookings-Harbor school board is asking for assistance in selecting the district’s next superintendent. The Board will be selecting up to 18 individuals (staff and non-staff) to assist in the application screening and interview process to be held on the dates listed below.
6:30 pm, January 16
6:30 pm, January 23
Times TBD, February 1-5

If interested, please complete an application. Completed/signed applications due to District Office by 4 pm on December 6th, 2019. If you have additional questions please call 541-469-7443.
https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/news/article/1130302

—
District Leadership Team expanding to add community members

Brookings-Harbor School District is looking for five (5) community members for the DLT Team. They can email Dede Corpening or contact the district office to express interest. Must be available for meetings on the following dates:
* 4 to 6:30 p.m. Dec. 10, 2019
* 4 to 6:30 p.m. March 4, 2019
* 4 to 6:30 p.m. May 6, 2019

https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/news/article/1130331

—
More ways to get involved:

General district and classroom volunteer information: http://www.brookings.k12.or.us/volunteer/

Join the Parent Teacher Organization (PTO): https://kes.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1393898&type=d&pREC_ID=1572437

Join the Brookings Harbor Booster Club

post_text:
Week of Thankfulness - Day 1

The Career Technical Education program at Brookings-Harbor High School would like to thank the Brookings Harbor Education Foundation for a grant donation of $1,000 to purchase metal for student welding and fabrication projects in the metals lab. This generous grant will be spent locally to provide raw materials that students can create with, and will support student success in learning new skills working with metals and welding.

Last week was an exciting week for our program with the final phase of the installation of a new ventilation system underway. The team from Umpqua Sheet Metal of Roseburg has been working hard with our school district facilities and maintenance team to complete the installation and wiring. When complete, students will be able to push a button in individual welding booths to activate the vents.

The metals program also welcomes community-driven project suggestions for things that can be utilized by the community that students can create. For further information, please contact teacher Chris Thompson via email at christ@brookings.k12.or.us.

Since September, BHEF has provided more than $1,900 in grants to Brookings-Harbor School District classrooms and programs. In addition to the recent donation to Chris Thompson’s welding and metals classes at BHHS, there have also been mini-grants to help purchase robotics “Bots” kits for Jennifer Bietschek’s math classes at Azalea Middle School, tree planting materials for K’la Kennedy and Kelly Margolis’ kindergarten classes at Kalmiopsis Elementary, and further support for prizes and materials for the district-wide Oregon Battle of the Books program coordinated by District Librarian Patty Clark and her team. Thank you BHEF for your support!

post_text:
3 Actions to Fight Flu

One, get vaccinated.

Two, help stop the spread of flu viruses.

Three, take antiviral drugs if your doctor prescribes them.

Fight flu. www.cdc.gov/flu
text:
3 Actions to Fight Flu

One, get vaccinated.

Two, help stop the spread of flu viruses.

Three, take antiviral drugs if your doctor prescribes them.

Fight flu. www.cdc.gov/flu

post_text:
Message from BHSD Nurse Trish Walker:
Flu season started on October 1st and continues until March 31st. During our last flu season, the CDC estimated that there were 40 million flu-related illnesses, up to 647,000 flu hospitalizations, and between 36,400 and 61,200 flu deaths.

The flu is spread easily through tiny droplets produced when people with the flu talk, cough, or sneeze. Touching surfaces with the flu virus on them and then touching your mouth, nose or possibly eyes can also spread the infection, although this occurs less frequently.

People are most likely to spread the flu during the first three to four days of their illness. Flu symptoms may include fever, chills, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, muscle or body aches, headaches, fatigue, and sometimes nausea and vomiting.

If you get the flu, try to avoid contact with sick people. Keep your hands away from your mouth; cover your coughs and sneezes; wash your hands often, and keep surfaces clean.

The best prevention is to get vaccinated. The local pharmacies offer flu vaccines, as do most health care providers.

Video text:

Take three actions to fight the flu. One, get vaccinated. Two, help stop the spread of flu viruses. Three, take antiviral drugs if your doctor prescribes them. Fight flu. www.cdc.gov/flu

post_text:
It's not too late: 2019 Community Survey is open until Sunday, Oct. 27th!

Answer two questions to help shape the future of your schools:
-What is going well in Brookings-Harbor schools?
-What can we improve?

Take the survey in english:
https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/form/2019-ssa-input

Encuesta comunitaria de 2019 en español:
https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/form/encuesta-2019

--
What will my responses be used for?
The results of the survey will be used to inform the school district's continuous improvement plan and determine funding priorities for new funds available through the Student Success Act.

What is the Student Success Act?
Signed into law in May of 2019, the Student Success Act is a historic opportunity for Oregon schools. When fully implemented this act will invest approximately $2 billion for early learning and K-12 education, and close to $500 million will go directly to Oregon school districts and eligible charter schools through the Student Investment Account. This account is a non-competitive grant. The focus of the Student Investment Account is on key areas for improvement – from reducing class size, increasing instructional time, addressing health and safety needs and ensuring a well-rounded education. The law requires school districts to meaningfully engage stakeholders to determine the best investments for students in their local community while explicitly focusing on student mental and behavior health, addressing disparities based on race or disability, and improving teaching and learning conditions.

More information: www.brookings.k12.or.us/survey/

Brookings-Harbor School District 17-C
Special School Board Meeting
Azalea Middle School Library
Tuesday, October 22, 2019, 7:30 PM
AGENDA
1. Call Meeting to Order
2. Community/Staff input for the qualities and qualifications for the new superintendent
3. Adjournment
The meeting location is accessible to persons with disabilities. A request for an interpreter for the hearing impaired, or other accommodations for persons with disabilities should be made at least 48 hours in advance of the meeting. Please contact the district office at 541-469-7443.

If you missed the survey and can’t make the school board meeting, please feel free to reach out to our interim superintendent Chris Eberhardt, school board members or assistant to the board Dede Corpening directly over email with your ideas or concerns. Thank you to all the staff and community members who shared their thoughts so far!

and

post_text:
Help spread the word: BHSD now accepting applications for 2-year appointment to Budget Committee.

The Brookings-Harbor School Board is seeking to fill three vacancies on the Budget Committee. The one-page application is available below as a PDF or Word document on our website (https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1399017&type=d&pREC_ID=1626650) and is due to the School District office by Friday, Oct. 4, 2019. Please bring by the office at 564 Fern Ave., Brookings, OR 97415 or email to Dede Corpening at dedec@brookings.k12.or.us.

The Board will consider applications for appointment at the upcoming October School Board Meeting. Typically, the Budget Committee meets with the school board for training and series of annual meetings from March to June to set the budget for the coming year.

By state law and district policy, School District Budget Committee members must meet three criteria:
- Live within the geographic boundaries of District 17-C
- Be a registered voter in the State of Oregon.
- NOT be an employee or agent of District 17-C

Thank you to our volunteer school board and budget committee members for your financial stewardship!

Did you know? Our special programs team has moved from the district office building into a new space in the Student Services Center at 629 Easy Street. The other side of this building is the home of the BHHS School Based Health Center and access is via the high school parking lot.

The Student Services Center is open M-F from 7:30 am to 4:00 pm. Call 541-412-1488.

What are BHSD Student Services?
Special Education programs
School Psychology
Speech Language Pathology (SLP) Services
Occupational Therapy (OT) Services
Physical Therapy (PT) Services
Autism Services
Extended School Year (ESY) Services
Behavior Support Services
504 Services
Health Services
English Language Development and Title III
Indian Education
Homeless Student Services (McKinney-Vento Act)
Youth Transition Program (YTP)
Foster Child/Student Services
Talented and Gifted (TAG) Enrichment Services

July 30, 2019 at 3:10 PM ·

It’s that time again when more feet (and wheels) hit the street. So please, drive slowly through school zones and keep your mind free from distractions. Keeping kids safe – it’s another way Oregonians Stand Out.

post_text:
The Back-to-School Community Breakfast was celebrated with music and a performance from the band and color guard, introductions, thank yous, and breakfast for a crowd of more than 300 on Tuesday morning at the Brookings-Harbor High School cafeteria. Newly hired interim superintendent Chris Eberhardt was in attendance and provided a special presentation after breakfast. Sharon Tovey of KURY Radio announced the results of the annual Stuff the Bus School Supply Drive, which included a mountain of school supplies such as notebooks and crayons collected from the community, a special donation of backpacks from the Salvation Army, and a check for just over $1,828. Thank you to all who donated to give our teachers and students tools to succeed this year and to these Stuff the Bus program sponsors:

Umpqua Bank
Harbrook Jewelers
Curry Health Network
Barron’s Home Furnishings
Coos-Curry Electric Cooperative, Inc.
Curry Coastal Pilot
McDonalds
The Salvation Army
Brookings-Harbor Lions Club

post_text:
This is the last week of the free summer meals program. Breakfast and lunch served at the high school cafeteria daily until Thursday, Aug. 22. All are welcome!

This week is also the first week of fall athletics and activities tryouts. If you have questions or still need to fulfill your "Gold Card" requirements (Family ID registration completed, fees paid, sports physical on file, etc.) call your school office.

Next week will be a teacher in-service week with a new teacher and staff orientation on Monday, Aug. 26 and all returning teachers and staff kicking off the new year on Tuesday, Aug. 27 with the community breakfast celebration, training and classroom set-up.

Only 15 days until the first week of school! Can you believe it?

Register for Kalmiopsis Elementary, Azalea Middle School, and Brookings-Harbor High School.

Q: When's the first day of school for my student?

A: Depends on grade level and whether or not they are new to the district (transferring in from another school or homeschool).

Check out this handy infographic that details the first week.

You can see the official 2019-2020 academic calendar at https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/news/article/1026819

Sharing this reminder from one of our coaches: Athletics and activities physical are required every two years. If you need a form to take to your medical provider’s office, you can download one from the OSAA website at http://www.osaa.org/docs/forms/PhysicalExamination-English2017.pdf

Curry Community Health is holding a clinic at the School-Based Health Center on Wednesday and Thursday this week for those who are interested.

Reminder: Today is Wednesday and on Wednesdays we have a special activity and picnic storytime in The Bridge Garden next to the Brookings-Harbor High School cafeteria during the free summer meals program. Today’s activity theme is “Garden In a Glove” and the book is “How a Plant Grows” read by a special guest reader.

Today’s lunch menu at the school is: Spaghetti with Meatballs, Garlic Bread, Green Tossed Salad, and Vine Ripe Grapes.

Today’s lunch menu on the BOB Bus is: Cucumber Bagel, Italian Tossed Salad, Vine Ripe Grapes, and Chips.

More information on summer meals: http://www.brookings.k12.or.us/summerfood/

post_text:
Have you visited the Bites of Brookings “BOB” bus yet?

The bus makes four stops daily Monday to Friday to serve lunch from July 8 to Aug. 2. Free meals for all youth ages 1-18. Adults can dine with their child for $3.75. The planned stops are:

- 11:30 a.m. to 11:45 p.m. - Harbor Rural Fire Protection District, 98069 W. Benham Way, Harbor
- 11:50 a.m. to 12:05 p.m. - RE/MAX Coast & Country, W. Hoffeldt Lane, Harbor
- 12:10 to 12:40 p.m. - Kemp Auto Sales (South Entrance), 16365 Old U.S. Highway 101, Harbor
- 12:45 to 1 p.m. - Chetco Community Public Library, 405 Alder St., Brookings

You can also get breakfast and lunch M-Th at the Brookings-Harbor High School cafeteria. Don’t miss out on special picnic storytime Wednesdays in The Bridge Garden next to the cafeteria.

For more information, see http://www.brookings.k12.or.us/summerfood/

🍉

post_text:
On July 5, 2019, the Brookings-Harbor School District Board of Directors accepted the resignation of Superintendent Sean Gallagher, who served the district since 2015. The board has begun the process to initiate a search for an interim superintendent utilizing the Oregon School Boards Association (OSBA) and other outside resources.

A special board meeting will be held at 4 p.m. Tuesday, July 9, in the Azalea Middle School Library, 505 Pacific Ave. At the meeting, there will be an opportunity for members of the community to provide input on the qualities and qualifications desired for the interim superintendent. For more information on the agenda, see the BoardBook at http://www.brookings.k12.or.us/board/.

A special board meeting will be held at 4 p.m. Tuesday, July 9, in the Azalea Middle School Library, 505 Pacific Ave. At the meeting, there will be an opportunity for members of the community to provide input on the qualities and qualifications desired for the interim superintendent. For more information on the agenda, see the BoardBook at http://www.brookings.k12.or.us/board/.

post_text:
Sharing for Chetco Community Public Library:

Public Library Summer Reading Launch Party is coming up!

This event will feature a free food, games, prizes… and for the little ones, a touch-a-truck party! There will be all sorts of emergency service vehicles in the lot for kids to explore, including ambulances, fire trucks, and coast guard vessels. Library staff will be on hand to assist with signups for our Summer Reading Program, which will feature activities and contests for children AND adults. This year’s theme for Summer Reading is “A Universe of Stories,” and will run July 1 through August 17.

Where: The Library Parking Lot

When: Saturday, June 29, 1:00-3:00pm

Who’s Invited? Everyone!

To learn more about our Summer Reading Program, find summer reading lists, and download reading logs, please visit our Summer Reading page at http://chetcolibrary.org/srp/

post_text:
Another great support group opportunity for grandparents raising grandkids!

---
We are pleased to announce that we will be hosting a second Family Café for your group (Grandparents Raising their Grandchildren). During this Café, we will have a facilitated discussion time specifically for the grandchildren, acknowledging that they are there with others who are also being raised by their grandparents.

The children will head across the street to the Library Annex after our family meal time, where they will have their discussion time, followed by an activity and time to enjoy the outdoor garden and green space.

Applications are also available for the UpLift summer camp. Advanced Health is sponsoring a limited number of week-long scholarships specifically for grandchildren aged K-5th grade, who are both covered by OHP and who are being raised by their grandparents.

Also, below is a recap of some fun and free activities and services available to children this summer:

- KASPER (Kids After School Program of Education and Recreation) www.kasperkids.org
- FREE swimming on Saturdays sponsored for Advance Health at the Brookings pool, Saturdays beginning June 22nd from 12-4 pm, thru Aug. 31.
- FREE breakfasts and lunches hosted at Brookings Harbor High School with an activity on Wednesdays following lunch.
- Harmony & Me music has offered gift certificates for the intergenerational music classes (Mona Chandler with CASA) has the Certificates

Thank you and we look forward to seeing you on June 25th at the Chetco Public Library for our 2nd Family Café from 5:30-7:30 pm.

post_text:
As we end this school year, a heartfelt THANK YOU goes out to two departing school board members for their many years of service on the Brookings-Harbor School District Board of Directors.

Board Chairman Bruce Raleigh joined in 2013 and Board Member Sue Gold has served since 2015.

At their final meeting on Wednesday evening, the pair received gifts of appreciation created by Brookings-Harbor High School students and staff including ceramic tiles in Myrtlewood stands from Sheryl Tuttle's Art and Ceramics and Gary Suter's Woodworking classes; canned preserves from Michelle Prudden's Youth Transition Program; and custom garden markers created by Arnold Wardwell's Welding classes.

post_text: Have you had a chance to take the community survey that is gathering information about the feasibility of creating an event center in the Brookings-Harbor area? An all-volunteer task force has received support from the Ford Family Foundation to gather information and is seeking your input!
shared_text:
Dennett Consulting Group
May 30, 2019 at 7:12 AM ·

SURVEY CLOSES TODAY, JUNE 24TH AT 5 PM --- BROOKINGS COMMUNITY SURVEY - The all-volunteer Brookings Harbor Events & Performing Arts Center Task Force (EPAC) is exploring the need for a local event center. The first step is a community survey and we have been asked to help gather responses to this survey. If you live in the greater Brookings area we would appreciate if you could take a few minutes to complete this survey:
www.research.net/r/Brookings2019

As a token of the Task Force’s appreciation, all participants will be entered into a drawing for a $100 VISA GIFT CARD. Thank you in advance for helping the Task Force understand the needs of the community.

post_text:
Can you believe it? Tomorrow is the last day of school at Kalmiopsis Elementary, Azalea Middle School, and Brookings-Harbor High School. It's also an early release day, so expect the usual half-day schedule.

K-School students will participate in the annual Flag Day ceremony at 8:30 a.m. Thursday followed by the PBIS (Positive Behavior Interventions and Supports) drawing where students who earned tickets for good behavior are eligible to win some exciting grand prizes.

AMS students will enjoy an "Olympics" field day starting at 11:15 p.m. just before heading home!

DONT FORGET: The PTO is hosting an 8th Grade Moving-On Ceremony at 6 p.m. Thursday at Azalea.

BHHS students will be finishing up final exams and projects.

Congratulations on a year well-done everyone!

post_text:
From May 29 to 31, our sixth-grade students at Azalea Middle School participated in Outdoor School for the first time in many years thanks to new funding from the State and a hardworking local planning committee led by AMS Principal Nicole Medrano.

We partnered with Coyle Outside to bring a rich outdoor experience to all AMS students, with a variety of hands-on learning activities.

Outdoor School has a more than 60 year legacy in Oregon. In July 2017, the Oregon Legislature formally approved $24 million for the statewide Outdoor School program over the next two years. This followed Oregon voters’ approval of Ballot Measure 99 in November 2016 to provide a statewide Outdoor School program.
shared_text:
Azalea Middle School
June 1, 2019 at 7:27 AM ·

Day 3: Final Day of Outdoor School
Was spent working on Navigation, Fish anatomy/cleaning, Primitive shelter, Shock and Utility Plants. It was a blast!

Thank you for parents, staff, and students for supporting such a memorable experience.

A special thanks to Coyle Outside for providing hands-on outdoor learning!!!

post_text:
The Brookings-Harbor School District 2019 Summer Food Program will run June 24 to August 8. Breakfast will be served from 8:30 a.m. to 9:15 a.m. and lunch will be served from 11:45 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. Monday through Thursday, at the Brookings-Harbor High School cafeteria, 625 Pioneer Road. The food program will close for the Independence Day holiday on Thursday, July 4.

In addition to providing free healthy meals to children ages 18 and younger at no cost; parents and family members are welcome to join in! Adult meals cost $2.75 for breakfast and $3.75 for lunch daily at the cafeteria. Fresh food from the school district gardens is included in the salad bar when available.

Every Wednesday at 11:30 a.m. a fun educational activity is offered in the garden next to the cafeteria followed by a picnic story time where families can bring their lunches outside to enjoy!

Stay tuned, more information coming soon ...

post_text:
Today we celebrate our amazing Food Service Department with School Lunch Hero Day! Between preparing healthy meals for America’s students, adhering to strict nutrition standards, navigating student food allergies, and offering service with a smile, school nutrition professionals are true heroes.

Friday, May 3, 2019, is the 7th Annual School Lunch Hero Day! School Lunch Hero Day is a chance to showcase the difference school nutrition professionals make for every child who comes through the cafeteria.

THANK YOU! We are so grateful for you! ❤️

post_text:
Our district Multicultural Club is hosting the 3rd Annual Cinco de Mayo event this Friday May 3rd from 5-7 pm at BHHS Cafeteria. Please come and enjoy great homemade Mexican food, games and a special traditional dance performance from the Smith River Folklorico Dancers.

Food plates are $9 and come with 2 tacos, rice, beans, chips and a drink. There will also be lots of other Mexican snacks and treats for sale. All proceeds go to district-wide multicultural activities including Chinese New Year, Hanukkah, Greek Orthodox Easter, Indian Holi and more!!!!

We will have games, a piñata, a photo booth and more.

Hope to see you all there!!

It has been reported to Brookings-Harbor School District that someone has been calling local people and businesses and soliciting the purchase of advertisements for a Fall 2019 BHHS football program. The BHHS Historical Society Club is currently looking for donations to be used for an alumni exhibit they are creating for the Chetco Valley Historical Society Museum over Memorial Day weekend for the 80th Annual Azalea Festival. (Brookings Harbor Azalea Festival)

They are looking for photographs, rare items, and yearbooks that people would be willing to donate permanently to the display.

If you are willing to donate, you can drop off donations at Brookings-Harbor High School or call or email the teacher and club advisor Kelly Garvin at 541-469-2108 or kellyg@brookings.k12.or.us.

post_text:
Reminder for parents/guardians:

Brookings-Harbor School District has partnered with My MealTime, a fast, secure online service for making credit or debit card deposits and monitoring your student’s lunch account. You may also be able to make other school payments such as sports/activities fees, yearbook purchases, library fines, fundraisers and more.*

Go to: www.mymealtime.com or download the mobile app

Easy steps to use My MealTime:
Step 1: Register. Click or tap the Register button and follow the onscreen prompts to create your My MealTime account.
Step 2: Link Your Student. Click or tap the ‘Add Student’ button, then find your student’s school. Link them to your profile by using their student ID number that was provided by your student’s school.
Step 3: Make a Deposit.** You may choose to store your credit/debit card for quick and easy repeat use.

My MealTime keeps you current
- Stay informed. Monitor your student’s lunch account activity.
- Be notified. Email reminders tell you when your student’s account is low.
- Schedule deposits. Weekly, monthly or in any frequency you choose.
- Make secure payments. Using your credit or debit card.**

Need help?
- Read the ‘Frequently Asked Questions’ (FAQ) under the ‘About’ section of the menu.
- Email your questions to our Support Team at: support@mealtimeclm.com

*Your school or district chooses which fees to make available on My MealTime.
** A small transaction fee will be assessed.

post_text:
Flooding and Landslide Advisory - April 8, 2019, 6:24 a.m.

Our BHSD17C Director of Transportation has been out checking bus routes for safety late last night and early this morning.

Reported landslides on North Bank Chetco River Road (Route B - Bus 67) and Winchuck River Road (Route C - Bus 66) are not within our bus routes, and those routes will run as normal - Winchuck River Road has one-lane traffic control at slide.

However, a slide on South Bank Chetco River Road has cut off part of our regular bus route (Route F - Bus 61). The new turn around point and final stop for this route will be Blackberry Lane. Stops at Mt. Emily Road and 99804 S. Bank Road will not have morning pick-up.

All staff and students, please exercise caution when traveling to campus this morning and call your school if you will not be able to come in due to flooding or road conditions in your area.

For detailed information on our bus routes, see http://brookings.k12.or.us/bus/
or
https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1399057&type=d&pREC_ID=1577612

For latest local information and road closures, check the Curry County Emergency Services Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/currycountyemergencyservices/) and TripCheck (https://www.tripcheck.com/).
