post_text:
Help spread the word!

The district is currently seeking applicants to fill two very important roles at Brookings-Harbor High School for the coming school year: Principal and Assistant Principal.

Brookings-Harbor School District recently received the resignations of Lisa Dion, Brookings-Harbor High School Principal; and Mark Hebert, BHHS Assistant Principal. Both plan to leave at the end of June.

Ms. Dion has served the district for five school years as BHHS Principal coming from Tillamook School District, and Mr. Hebert for one year arriving from Bend-LaPine School District. During Ms. Dion’s tenure, the graduation rate has risen to just below the state average after a long time period of very low percentages in comparison to other school districts. During Mr. Hebert’s tenure, he started the truancy court program in partnership with the City of Brookings which has resulted in a 25% decrease of absences overall at BHHS.

As of last week, both positions are posted to the district hiring website and shared on regional and national search websites. The district will be implementing a comprehensive process with staff input to find effective leaders who are a good fit and can carry on the important work already established. Any questions in regards to the hiring process can be directed to Dede Corpening – HR Assistant and/or Sean Gallagher – Superintendent at 541-469-7443.

More information and application for high school principal:
https://www.applitrack.com/brookings/onlineapp/default.aspx?Category=Administration&AppliTrackJobId=486&AppliTrackLayoutMode=detail&AppliTrackViewPosting=1

More information and application for high school assistant principal: https://www.applitrack.com/brookings/onlineapp/default.aspx?Category=Administration&AppliTrackJobId=487&AppliTrackLayoutMode=detail&AppliTrackViewPosting=1

More information about current open positions with BHSD: https://www.applitrack.com/brookings/onlineapp/

Apply for a substitute teaching or temporary position with BHSD: https://ess.com/

post_text:
Construction crews are busy working on Azalea Middle School during Spring Break. Prepare come back to some beautiful new floors and windows. The upgrades are funded through grants.

Thank you, Ausland Group!
shared_text:
Azalea Middle School
March 27, 2019 at 12:31 PM ·

Azalea Middle School underwent an extensive seismic safety retrofit last summer, but there were still a few finishing touches left to do. During this Spring Break, the AMS front offices are replacing worn out carpet with new flooring, and new windows are being installed in the library and hallway.

The retrofit and remodel is funded as part of the $4.5 million in grants from Business Oregon that the district has won for seismic safety projects in the past few years. Ausland Group of Grants Pass, working with local subcontractors, has covered all phases of the project.

#everystudentcansucceed #gobruins #bruinpride

post_text:
Thank you to Wild Rivers Community Foundation and the Brattain Family Student Enrichment Fund for your generous grant in support of the Brookings-Harbor High School Knowledge Bowl Team. With this recent grant, the team is able to cover the last $400 needed for travel and educational expenses while attending the NAQT Small Schools National Championship Tournament in Chicago, May 3-5.

The undefeated Bruin Knowledge Bowl team qualified for both the Overall High School National Championship (Atlanta, Georgia, May 24-26) and the Small Schools National Championship (Chicago, Illinois, May 3-5) during a statewide regional meet hosted at Brookings-Harbor High School on Jan. 26. The team is excited to attend the Small Schools National Championship, as the top-ranked team representing Oregon next month.

#bruinpride #everystudentcansucceed #gobruins
text:
Thank you to Wild Rivers Community Foundation and the Brattain Family Student Enrichment Fund for your generous grant in support of the Brookings-Harbor High School Knowledge Bowl Team. With this recent grant, the team is able to cover the last $400 needed for travel and educational expenses while attending the NAQT Small Schools National Championship Tournament in Chicago, May 3-5.

The undefeated Bruin Knowledge Bowl team qualified for both the Overall High School National Championship (Atlanta, Georgia, May 24-26) and the Small Schools National Championship (Chicago, Illinois, May 3-5) during a statewide regional meet hosted at Brookings-Harbor High School on Jan. 26. The team is excited to attend the Small Schools National Championship, as the top-ranked team representing Oregon next month.

#bruinpride #everystudentcansucceed #gobruins

post_text:
Congratulations to Brookings-Harbor High School senior Aynika Nelson, for representing BHHS and the Southern Oregon Region at the Oregon Arts Commission’s annual Poetry Out Loud Contest on March 9 in Salem. Aynika was one of just nine students from around the state selected for the statewide finals.

Details: https://www.oregonartscommission.org/sites/default/files/news/file/2019%20Poetry%20Out%20Loud%20winners%20release%20final.pdf

Poetry Out Loud: National Recitation Contest #poetryoutloud #gobruins #bruinpride
shared_text:
Oregon Arts Commission
March 5, 2019 at 7:22 PM ·

Congratulations to the nine students who will compete for Oregon’s Poetry Out Loud: National Recitation Contest title Saturday!

Regional Poetry Out Loud competitions held in Medford, Portland and Salem March 2 identified the nine Oregon high school students who are invited to compete for the 2019 state title on Saturday, March 9. Three finalists were selected from each regional competition.

The winners of the Southern Regional Contest, hosted at Rogue Community College, are: Aynika Nelson, Brookings - Harbor High School, Brookings; Megan Southard, Bonanza Jr./Sr. High School, Klamath Falls; and Hannah VonHolle, Logos Public Charter School, Medford.

The three top finishers from the Portland Regional Contest, held at Lewis and Clark College, are: Christina Brennan, Oregon Connections Academy, Mill City; Belise Nishimwe, St. Mary's Academy, Portland; and Kaiden Randall, West Linn High School.

Finalists selected at the Central Regional Contest at Salem’s Allied Video Productions Studio are: Nicole Coronado, Lakeridge High School, Lake Oswego; Amy Jarvie, Oregon School for the Deaf, Salem (2018 state runner up); and Gabriella Shirtcliff, Summit High School, Bend.

We are so proud of all of them!

Read the full release: https://bit.ly/2TuWmSv

#IamPoetryOutLoud

post_text: It's been a stellar year for our schools and students in terms of earning trips to state and national competitions. Congratulations to Noah, who will represent Azalea Middle School at the State National Geographic Geo Bee competition later this month.
shared_text:
Azalea Middle School
March 11, 2019 at 11:32 AM ·

6th grader Noah Speir headed to the state GeoBee finals!

On January 16, Azalea Middle School hosted its annual Geography Bee, where students answer increasingly challenging questions about world geography to determine a winner.

We are very proud of 6th grader Noah Speir, who not only won our local school competition but qualified for the statewide contest. Noah will travel to the National Geographic Geo Bee State Competition Friday, March 29, at Western Oregon University in Monmouth.

There, he will compete for a top prize of $1000 and a trip to Washington, D.C. for the National Championship. We love our student's curiosity about the world and quest for knowledge. Please join all of us here at AMS in wishing Noah well as he represents us at State!

https://sites.google.com/site/oregonstatebee/

post_text: Congratulations, Azalea Middle School Llamas! Way to take Brookings-Harbor all the way to State for Oregon Battle of the Books.
shared_text:
Azalea Middle School
March 11, 2019 at 11:19 AM ·

Our Azalea Middle School team, the "Miniature Literature Libro Llamas" took second place at the southern Oregon regionals in Rogue River on Saturday. Region 5 had 20 teams competing and will send two teams to the state competition on April 6 at Chemeketa Community College in Salem. So, that means that our Llamas are "state-bound"!! Congratulations!

Last Saturday's regional competition started with "pool play" where each team competed in four battles and points were accumulated. The top 16 scoring teams went on to "bracket play" with the "Llamas" ranked No. 1 after pool points were counted. In the regional finals, they lost to Ashland Middle School, who is last year's defending State Champion at the middle school level.

Way to go, Alyssum, Acacia, Daisha, and Alison! Good luck at State!

🦙📚🏅

#BruinBride #EveryStudentCanSucceed #GoBruins #OBOB #OBOB2019

post_text:
It's National School Breakfast Week (March 4-8, 2019)!

Here are 5 tasty facts about food service in our schools - Did you know?

1. Kalmiopsis Elementary is a Provision 2 school. This means we serve FREE breakfast and lunch daily to all Kalmiopsis students. Azalea Middle School and Brookings-Harbor High School provide free and reduced meals to students who qualify. Find daily menus at https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/menus/.

2. Kalmiopsis Elementary launched a "Breakfast in the Classroom" in Fall 2017. Every day, students have the opportunity to eat a free, simple breakfast after the bell in their classroom, providing them with the nutrition needed to succeed throughout the school day.

3. In the summer, the school district hosts the Summer Food Program, where youth ages 1-18 can eat free breakfast and lunch Monday to Thursday in the Brookings-Harbor High School cafeteria. Adults can dine with their kids for just $2.50 at breakfast and $3.75 at lunch.

4. Recently, our school district applied for and won a grant from the Oregon Department of Education's Child Nutrition Programs! Starting this summer, we will reach even more youth in need in our Brookings-Harbor community and surrounding rural neighborhoods. We are retrofitting a full-size school bus into a meal delivery vehicle and a dining car that will make daily stops in neighborhoods across our community.

5. The Summer Food Program daily salad bar incorporates farm-to-table produce from the school gardens! And, did you know that Kalmiopsis Elementary is a “Monarch School USA” — one of just a handful across the country? This summer, we will host enrichment activities with hands-on opportunities to learn about gardens, food, and nutrition through a partnership with “Ag in the Classroom” for Summer Food Program participants.

#NSBW #NSBW19 #schoolbreakfast

It's Classified Staff Appreciation Week, March 4-8! We value our classified staff and all the work they do for our Brookings-Harbor schools and programs, and for our students each day.

Who are our Classified Staff? In our district that includes Playground Aides, Food Service Workers, Secretaries, Custodians, Maintenance Workers, Computer Techs, Bus Drivers, Library Techs, Life Skills AIdes, Teaching and Specialist Assistant Positions, and even an Accompanist for our music program.

THANK YOU! #gobruins #bruinpride #everystudentcansucceed.

Kalmiopsis Elementary
Azalea Middle School
Brookings-Harbor High School

Brookings-Harbor High School
February 22, 2019 at 12:25 AM ·

Members of the Brookings-Harbor High School Knowledge Bowl team react with surprise to the unveiling of a check for $2,000 from the Brookings-Harbor Education Foundation, Inc., to help fund their upcoming trip to the National Quiz Bowl Tournament in Chicago May 3-5.

Brookings-Harbor School District 17C thanks BHEF, and all the generous service clubs, foundations, donors, boosters and community volunteers in our community who help bring these types of special activities within reach for our students. #gobruins #bruinpride #everystudentcansucceed.

Read more: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/news/article/999510
--
Photo 1: From left to right, Team Co-Advisor Lei’La’ Bryant, Natalie Garcia, Isabella Freitas, Abby Marks, Aynika Nelson, Nevaeh Meyer, Cecilia Hilton, BHEF Board Member Brandon Hodges, BHSD17C Superintendent Sean Gallagher, BHEF Board President Alisa Green, BHEF Board Member K’La Kennedy, BHEF Board Member Nancy Chew, Ethan Hooper (also a BHEF student rep), and BHEF Board Member Val Cowan. Not pictured: Knowledge Bowl Co-Advisor Lisa Piscitello, Nathaniel Barnard, Maxim Drager, Spencer Miller, Kelvon’te Dawsey, and Danika Leaver; and BHEF Board Members Gayle Goldstone, Patty McVay, and BHEF student rep Charlie Nolte.

Photo 2: Team photo by Judith Durkin

post_text:
Last night our School Board of Directors approved this new MOU with the City of Brookings, Oregon to bring a Brookings Police Department Officer back to campus to serve as an SRO.

“The main role of an effective SRO can be summarized as prevention, but they are also available to reach out to in any safety situations that may occur. In addition, law enforcement is an excellent career pathway for students to consider, and the physical presence of an SRO will most likely provide opportunities for students to explore this path.”

post_text:
Have you checked in on your student's attendance lately?

Did you know? There’s a close connection between school attendance and high school graduation. If you or someone you know is experiencing challenges that interfere with school attendance, our community has many ways to help. From housing and transportation challenges to emotional kids who simply don’t want to go to school, we can help troubleshoot. Visit Every-Day-Matters.org to learn more.

#EveryDayMatters #Attendance #EveryStudentCanSucceed
text:
Have you checked in on your student's attendance lately?

Did you know? There’s a close connection between school attendance and high school graduation. If you or someone you know is experiencing challenges that interfere with school attendance, our community has many ways to help. From housing and transportation challenges to emotional kids who simply don’t want to go to school, we can help troubleshoot. Visit Every-Day-Matters.org to learn more.

#EveryDayMatters #Attendance #EveryStudentCanSucceed

SOCC Curry Campus joins the list of delayed starts for this morning.

UPDATED 5:45 AM TUESDAY FEB. 5: Brookings-Harbor School District will have a two-hour delayed start Tuesday, Feb. 5. All school start times, and bus routes pick-up times will be delayed 2 hours.

Route B (Bus 67) will pick up Gardner Ridge Road students at the "snow day" stop at the Upper Chetco Rural Fire Protection District building at the corner of Gardner Ridge and Lewis Creek Road.

Other public school districts across the South Coast region that have announced a 2-hour delay for Feb. 5 include Central Curry School District (Gold Beach), Port Orford-Langlois School District, Bandon School District, and Coos Bay School District. Locally, Southwestern Oregon Commuity College Curry Campus and Brookings Harbor Christian School (private) has also announced a two-hour delay.

Kalmiopsis Elementary 9:45 a.m. delayed start time

Azalea Middle School 10:15 a.m. delayed start time

Brookings-Harbor High School 0 period delayed start time 9:10 a.m.; 1/2 period delayed start time 10:25 a.m.

UPDATED 5:45 AM TUESDAY FEB. 5: Brookings-Harbor School District will have a two-hour delayed start Tuesday, Feb. 5. All school start times, and bus routes pick-up times will be delayed 2 hours.

Route B (Bus 67) will pick up Gardner Ridge Road students at the "snow day" stop at the Upper Chetco Rural Fire Protection District building at the corner of Gardner Ridge and Lewis Creek Road.

The delay is due to winter weather concerns and possible icy road conditions in the early morning hours. Staff and students should report at 2 hours after their usual start time. School will end at the usual time.

Other public school districts across the South Coast region that have announced a 2-hour delay for Feb. 5 include Central Curry School District (Gold Beach), Port Orford-Langlois School District, Bandon School District, and Coos Bay School District. Locally, Brookings Harbor Christian School (private) has also announced a two-hour delay.

post_text:
ICYMI: The Brookings-Harbor High School Knowledge Bowl team is headed to Nationals in Chicago this May! Go Bruins! (https://www.naqt.com/ssnct/)

To help fund this trip of a lifetime, the school district is providing funds for hotel and competition registration. The team is fundraising for airfare and to experience some museums and activities while in the "Windy City" and has a fundraising goal of about $5000.

We appreciate the interest of local foundations and community members who have reached out and created fundraisers for the team or responded to donation requests from students. If you are interested in contributing, please contact the BHSD District Office or Knowledge Bowl team advisors Lei'La' Bryant and Lisa Piscitello. (https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1396588&type=d&pREC_ID=1574856)

More updates coming soon!

https://www.currypilot.com/home/6888924-151/undefeated-team-earns-trip-to-nationals

post_text:
Alert: ‘Snow Day’ Bus Route for Route B (Bus 67) students this morning

School is on; but Bus Route B (Gardner Ridge Road) has an updated pick-up location and schedule! Due to snowy weather conditions in the Gardner Ridge area, morning bus pick-up locations on Gardner Ridge Road are canceled, and a “snow day” bus stop will be available.

Pick-up for students who live up Gardner Ridge will be at the corner of North Bank Chetco River Road and Gardner Ridge Road. Please note: This pick up location is lower on the hill than the usual “snow day” bus stop by the rural fire district office.

Pick up time at this adjusted stop will be approximately 7 to 7:15 am.

http://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/news/article/988035

post_text:
With some potential for snow or ice in the weather forecast for tomorrow, Monday, Feb. 4, we just want to remind the community how and where we share school closure information: brookings.k12.or.us/schoolclosures/ (https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1399057&type=d&pREC_ID=1577666)

A more frequent scenario in our district is that school remains open, but there may be changes or cancelations to our bus routes in higher elevations (Gardner Ridge, Carpenterville Road, Cape Ferrello). If you live in these neighborhoods, do you know your "snow day" bus stop just in case? Find information listed here: brookings.k12.or.us/bus/ (https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1399057&type=d&pREC_ID=1577612)

Our Superintendent and Transportation Director will be up bright and early tomorrow checking routes and monitoring conditions throughout the day to make a decision as early as possible.

At this point, (4 p.m. Sunday, Feb. 3) school and all activities are on, as planned, for Monday.

post_text:
Bullying can lead to regular absences, not to mention trauma. If you suspect your child may be being bullied, it’s important to check in with the school. Children often resist this, worrying that it will make things worse, but your child’s safety is extremely important to us and we need to know. Learn more about bullying here: www.stopbullying.gov

Learn more about filing a complaint to BHSD17C: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1399057&type=d&pREC_ID=1577692

Use the anonymous SafeOregon Tipline to report an issue: https://www.safeoregon.com/report-a-tip/

#EveryDayMatters #Attendance

post_text:
Hop onboard for some exciting news about our Summer Food Program!

Recently, our school district applied for and won a $20,000 Summer Meal Program Start-Up and Expansion Grant from the Oregon Department of Educations’ Child Nutrition Programs! Starting next summer, this new grant will enable us to bring the Summer Food Program to even more youth in need in our Brookings-Harbor community and surrounding rural neighborhoods.

Brookings-Harbor School District plans to use the grant funds to retrofit a full-size school bus into a meal delivery vehicle and a dining car that will make daily stops in neighborhoods across our community.

Learn more about the project at: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/news/article/978889

Community resource alert:

The Shoe Bank will host the first giveaway of the new year from 1 to 3 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 12, at the Brookings-Harbor Elks Lodge, 800 Elk Dr, Brookings, OR 97415.

According to organizers of this volunteer project, they have some western boots, water waders, cleats, casual shoes for men, and slip-on's for women; and have also received a large donation of socks.

If you have questions, please contact Linda at 541-469-9850.
text:
Community resource alert:

The Shoe Bank will host the first giveaway of the new year from 1 to 3 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 12, at the Brookings-Harbor Elks Lodge, 800 Elk Dr, Brookings, OR 97415.

According to organizers of this volunteer project, they have some western boots, water waders, cleats, casual shoes for men, and slip-on's for women; and have also received a large donation of socks.

If you have questions, please contact Linda at 541-469-9850.

post_text:
Message shared by the Oregon Department of Education's Child Nutrition Programs today:

"Households affected by the partial closure of the federal government may apply for National School Lunch and School Breakfast meal benefits. The income guidelines for free and reduced-price school meals are based on annual income. These guidelines are broken down further to weekly, bi-weekly, twice a month and monthly level. Households may apply with the income received in the current month, projected for the month in which application is completed or for the month prior to application. In these unique circumstances, school districts should urge any families who are approved for free or reduced-price meals based on their reduced income during a furlough period to terminate their free/reduced price status should the economic hardship they had anticipated due to the furlough be remedied by a return to work and/or restoration of pay for the furlough period. In addition, families should be made aware that if they are selected for verification later in the school year, they will be required to produce documentation of actual income for the application month. School districts may choose to verify applications “for cause” if they have specific information indicating that the information on the application is not accurate."

Reminder: Students enrolled in Kalmiopsis Elementary already receive breakfast and lunch daily free of charge through the school's Provision 2 status. The circumstances outlined above may apply to middle and high school students in our district. If you know a family suffering economic hardship due to federal furlough or other reasons, please pass this message along.

The school bus is the only transportation option for some families. So, what happens if you miss the bus? Find out more about your back-up options so that you can get those kids to school even if you missed that ride!

Call or email OUR DISTRICT'S TRANSPORTATION OFFICE with questions, and always report a missed bus right away in case the school can swing back with another ride option shortly.

Allen Walz
Brookings-Harbor School District Transportation Director
541-469-2666
allenw@brookings.k12.or.us

#EveryDayMatters #Attendance

Learn more at https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/news/article/965536

post_text:
January 2019 is School Board Recognition Month in Oregon!

The Oregon School Boards Association has set aside the month of January to honor the unpaid elected volunteers who serve on Oregon’s 197 local school boards, our 19 education service district boards, and our 17 community college boards. These dedicated local leaders give their personal time and energy to handling the critical tasks of budgeting and overseeing the management of Oregon’s public education structure.

Brookings-Harbor School District's current board of directors is:
Sue Gold, School Board Member
Katherine Johnson, School Board Member
Alan Nidiffer, School Board Vice Chairperson
Bruce Raleigh, School Board Chairperson
Jay Trost, School Board Member

Thank you!

Join them at the regular school board meeting at 5 p.m. Wednesday, Jan. 9, in the Kalmiopsis Elementary library. To find more information on the BHSD17C school board, see https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=1399017&type=d&pREC_ID=1577230

post_text:
Did you know there’s a really close connection between school attendance and student success? Students who are chronically absent (that means they miss 10 percent of the year for excused or unexcused reasons) are much more likely to struggle in school and even have more trouble graduating. It makes sense because every day builds on the one before, making it easy to fall behind. Get tips on how to improve your child’s attendance at every-day-matters.org.

#EveryDayMatters #Attendance

post_text:
There’s one week left to purchase Katelyn's Cause Fundraiser Prize Drawing Tickets!

For the third year in a row, volunteers around the school district led by Molly Earl have organized a drawing to benefit Katelyn’s Cause.

Katelyn’s Cause is a local Brookings nonprofit that raises money to purchase gifts to be hand-delivered each December to children with cancer receiving treatment at Doernbecher Children’s Hospital in Portland, Oregon. Contributions to Katelyn’s Cause also enable gifts to be distributed over the entire year to patients battling cancer, sometimes even delivered the day the child is diagnosed.

Chis and Molly Wallace founded Katelyn’s Cause after losing their daughter Katelyn in 2008 to synovial sarcoma at the age of 17. Katelyn was a student of Brookings-Harbor schools.

Prizes in this year's drawing include:

* Two pairs of Legging Army leggings and a chicken pot pie, donated by Molly Earl. (Chicken pot pie will be made in the BHHS certified kitchen).
* A stained glass art piece, a framed floral painting by Cathy Dean, and a beautifully painted driftwood Santa, donated by Gina June.
* A painting donated by Ria Shanon, valued at $72.00.
* A candle basket, valued at $45.00, donated by Melissa’s Favorite Things.
* A one-month gym membership at Ironside Fitness in the Brookings Harbor Shopping Center valued at $50.00 & a gift certificate with personal trainer Nicole Stephens, valued at $200.00 donated by Fit With Nic.
* A basket of dog supplies by Sherri and Jennifer Legat.
* A Katelyn’s Cause T-Shirt and unity scarf.
* Myrtlewood wall art by Wade Stumpenhaus.
* Myrtlewood bowls, donated by Wade Stumpenhaus.
* A Maroon LuLaRoe Irma shirt, (size small), donated by Debbie Wesel; and two jars of locally sourced cranberry sauce, donated by Brookings-Harbor Youth Transition Program - Big Wave Catering.
* Brookings Oregon hats, patches and stickers, and South Coast scenic photography postcards donated by Studio RaCoon (Nancy Raskauskas-Coons), valued at $75.00.
* ... and more!

This is a community event, not just for school employees. The holder of the winning ticket need not be present to win. The drawing will take place on Wednesday, Dec. 19. Winners will be notified after 4 p.m.

Tickets will be sold until 3 p.m. Wednesday, Dec. 19. Tickets are $2 each, or 3 tickets for $5. To purchase, please call or text Molly Earl at (541) 661-2883 or mollye@brookings.k12.or.us; Molly Wallace, (at Kalmiopsis), Amy Garnier, (at Azalea Middle School), or Kristi Kleespies, (BHHS).

post_text:
Thank you Wild Rivers Community Foundation and partners for the generous Holiday Partnership Grant of $500 to the Brookings-Harbor High School Youth Transition Program (YTP).

The 2018 Holiday Partnership Grant funds are used to support a holiday meal for the students by purchasing four turkeys to provide a Thanksgiving dinner for the students enrolled in YTP Employability and YTP Exploring Careers classes. Students learn how to prepare a traditional holiday meal for themselves and their peers. Student-generated funds cover the other items needed to complete the meal.

The grant was also used to purchase locally sourced cranberries from Cape Blanco Cranberry Farms and canning jars/ supplies. The students learn how to process and can the cranberries into both whole berry and jellied cranberry sauce. The finished product is used as gifts for students, their families, and also given to the Brookings-Harbor Food Bank and two community kitchens.
shared_text:
Wild Rivers Community Foundation
November 15, 2018 at 8:37 PM ·

Wild Rivers Community Foundation presents $24,000 in holiday grants

Christmas came early for 32 nonprofit organizations in Curry and Del Norte counties that received grants totaling $24,000 from the Wild Rivers Community Foundation to provide children and adults with food, clothing and other critical supplies and services during the holidays. (See full list below.)

As part of its Holiday Partnership Grant program, the foundation awarded grants ranging from $250 to $2,000 using funds that came from community donors, including family trusts, foundations, business owners and individuals.

“There are many, great programs and projects in our community and these grants will help them accomplish their mission to help those in need during the holidays,” said WRCF Director Gina Zottola.

The organizations — from Klamath, California, to Port Orford, Oregon — applied for mini-grants to fund programs that provide children with winter coats or Christmas presents, holiday food for hungry families, warm clothes for struggling veterans and the homeless, and services for abused or neglected children.

The organizations will receive their grants and have the opportunity to talk about their programs during a reception at 6 p.m. Dec. 5 at Howonquet Hall in Smith River.

Wild Rivers Community Foundation (WRCF) is an affiliate of Humboldt Area Foundation, serving all of Del Norte and Curry counties. WRCF promotes and encourages generosity, leadership and inclusion to strengthen communities. For more information call 707-465-1238 or 541-412-6277, or visit wildriverscf.org.

2018 GRANTEES

Bicoastal Media, Curry and Del Norte counties: Coast for Kids
Boys and Girls Club of the Redwoods, Klamath, holiday basketball tournament

text:
Thank you Wild Rivers Community Foundation and partners for the generous Holiday Partnership Grant of $500 to the Brookings-Harbor High School Youth Transition Program (YTP).

The 2018 Holiday Partnership Grant funds are used to support a holiday meal for the students by purchasing four turkeys to provide a Thanksgiving dinner for the students enrolled in YTP Employability and YTP Exploring Careers classes. Students learn how to prepare a traditional holiday meal for themselves and their peers. Student-generated funds cover the other items needed to complete the meal.

The grant was also used to purchase locally sourced cranberries from Cape Blanco Cranberry Farms and canning jars/ supplies. The students learn how to process and can the cranberries into both whole berry and jellied cranberry sauce. The finished product is used as gifts for students, their families, and also given to the Brookings-Harbor Food Bank and two community kitchens.

Wild Rivers Community Foundation
November 15, 2018 at 8:37 PM ·

Wild Rivers Community Foundation presents $24,000 in holiday grants

Christmas came early for 32 nonprofit organizations in Curry and Del Norte counties that received grants totaling $24,000 from the Wild Rivers Community Foundation to provide children and adults with food, clothing and other critical supplies and services during the holidays. (See full list below.)

As part of its Holiday Partnership Grant program, the foundation awarded grants ranging from $250 to $2,000 using funds that came from community donors, including family trusts, foundations, business owners and individuals.

“There are many, great programs and projects in our community and these grants will help them accomplish their mission to help those in need during the holidays,” said WRCF Director Gina Zottola.

The organizations — from Klamath, California, to Port Orford, Oregon — applied for mini-grants to fund programs that provide children with winter coats or Christmas presents, holiday food for hungry families, warm clothes for struggling veterans and the homeless, and services for abused or neglected children.

The organizations will receive their grants and have the opportunity to talk about their programs during a reception at 6 p.m. Dec. 5 at Howonquet Hall in Smith River.

Wild Rivers Community Foundation (WRCF) is an affiliate of Humboldt Area Foundation, serving all of Del Norte and Curry counties. WRCF promotes and encourages generosity, leadership and inclusion to strengthen communities. For more information call 707-465-1238 or 541-412-6277, or visit wildriverscf.org.

post_text:
No school today - Monday, Nov. 12, 2018: Veterans Day Holiday (observed). Veterans Day, formerly known as Armistice Day, was set as a U.S. holiday to honor the end of World War I on Nov. 11, 1918 and now honors all armed forces veterans.

Did you know? The Brookings-Harbor High School WWII exhibit, "The Remembrance of World War II," is back on display locally at the Chetco Valley Historical Society Museum, 15461 Museum Rd, Brookings, OR 97415. This popular exhibit created last spring by 60 BHHS students under the instruction of Ms. Kelly Garvin was previously displayed at the Oregon Historical Society in downtown Portland in August, and debuted at Sea View Senior Living Community for the Azalea Days Festival and Memorial Day 2018.

This encore showing is the beginning of the newly formed Brookings-Harbor High School Historical Society working in partnership with the Chetco Valley Museum to help digitalize their history, work on community projects together, and create additional exhibits.

The WWII exhibit is in conjunction with the Museum’s membership drive. The museum agreed to donate $10 for every two members that sign-up to the school’s historical society to fund additional copies of ”Chetco: The story of a river and its people” textbook by Mike Adams for the BHHS Local History class, and to provide a budget for creating the next exhibit which will feature the history of Brookings-Harbor School District and it’s famous alumni.

For more information, see http://www.chetcomuseum.org.

post_text:
Great reminders! Help maintain safe routes to school for all students, whether they walk, ride the bus or are dropped off each day

This time of year, as twilight comes sooner and morning comes later, it is especially important that drivers be on high alert around our school buses. Every year, there are students injured around bus stops. According to research by the National Safety Council, most of the children who lose their lives in bus-related incidents are 4 to 7 years old, and they're walking. They are hit by the bus, or by a motorist illegally passing a stopped bus.

You can help prevent a tragedy: Increase your following distance and never pass a bus from behind or while it is stopped to load or unload children. It is illegal in all 50 states! All of our buses are equipped with video cameras. If a driver violates the requirement to stop their vehicle when the red lights flash, law enforcement will be contacted.

Next, as you approach the school campus, slow down and observe crosswalks, watch for pedestrians and cyclists and follow the instructions of crossing guards. At certain times of day, our parking areas and the streets around campus can become particularly congested. Stay patient. Observe the posted traffic flow and follow staff instructions. Do not linger in no-parking zones; do not double park, as it blocks visibility for other children and vehicles; and please do not use left-hand turns in order to keep the line moving!

Finally, don’t ever drive distracted in our school zones. In Oregon, using any function of your phone that requires holding or touching is outlawed while driving. Together, we must all do our part to keep our students safe and to ensure that “Every Student Can Succeed” here at Brookings-Harbor School District.

Del Norte County Unified School District
November 6, 2018 at 8:59 PM ·

It’s been a deadly week for kids at the bus stop. Tragedies in Florida, Indiana, Kentucky, Mississippi and Pennsylvania have left parents without children, and have drastically changed families, and communities across the country.

We are urging you to drive safely, and remember these rules about school bus safety:

https://dnusd.org/students__families/transportation/bus_safety_rules

Some athletics updates! #GoBruins

In soccer playoff action ...
- Girls soccer played Lakeview on Oct. 31st and won 3-2. They are now traveling to Portland to play Oregon Episcopal on Saturday, Nov. 3, in the quarterfinals at 4:30 p.m. A win will put them into the Semi-Finals with either St Mary's or Riverside.

- Boys Soccer played Rogue River on Oct. 30th and won 4-0. Tomorrow, Nov. 3, they will play Riverside in the quarterfinals here at BHHS @ 2 p.m. A win will put them into the Semi-Finals with either Oregon Episcopal or Santiam Christian.

Both soccer teams ended their seasons undefeated :)

- Cross Country had 9 athletes make it to the State Competition at Lane Community College in Eugene, Oregon. The race will be tomorrow, Saturday morning. The Boys were District Champs!

- Football left yesterday to travel to Salem to Play Amity High School in Amity Oregon tonight at 7 p.m. This is the first round of playoffs.

- Fundraiser: Powder Tuff is Nov. 9 at 7 p.m., this is volleyball tourney with boy's teams. The gate fees and fee to play go to Doernbecher's Children's Hospital in Portland.

http://www.osaa.org/schools/159

post_text:
THIS IS A DRILL! [All BHSD schools are taking part in the Great Oregon ShakeOut earthquake drill at 10:18 a.m. Thursday, Oct. 18]

This is the Great Oregon ShakeOut, one of the largest earthquake drills ever. Practice now so you can protect yourself during a real earthquake. This is an earthquake
drill. Right now, drop cover and hold on.

Drop to the floor, now. During a large earthquake, the ground might jerk strongly and knock you down.

Take cover under something sturdy to protect yourself from objects that can be thrown across the room.

Hold on to your shelter until the shaking stops. If you can't get under something, stay low and protect your head and neck with your arms.

Now, look around what objects might fall or be thrown at you, that you should secure in place before a real earthquake.

Finally, a strong earthquake may cause a tsunami. If you're near the ocean during an earthquake, drop cover and hold on. Then, quickly walk to high ground after the shaking stops.

This drill is over. Visit https://www.shakeout.org for simple steps to help you survive and recover from a major earthquake. Thank you for taking part in the Great ShakeOut.

See more ShakeOut resources for K-12 schools, here: https://www.shakeout.org/schools/

Drill video: https://youtu.be/__X_LkpVS2A

post_text:
Happy Homecoming, Bruins!

It's been a fun week of spirit activities at our elementary and middle school's such as Wear mix 'n' match blue on Monday; dress up as a twin day or favorite teacher on Tuesday; wear workout clothes Wednesday; PJ day on Thursday; and, of course, wear Blue & Gold Friday.

The high school leadership classes planned a slate of traditional events at the high school including today's Noise Parade for which the freshman, sophomores, juniors, and seniors were up late last night decorating floats to parade through town at approximately 2:30 p.m. They also planned a variety of philanthropy events and fundraisers that will continue through November and include an upcoming Blood Drive for the Red Cross.

Coronation of a homecoming king and queen will take place at tonight's home football game. Come and hear the BHHS marching and pep band! And, expect to see some dressed up students about town Saturday night for the annual homecoming dance.

#gobruins #bruinpride
shared_text:
CURRYPILOT.COM
BHHS Bruins 2018 Homecoming schedule

Brookings-Harbor High School
October 12, 2018 at 9:47 AM ·

Reminder: The Homecoming Noise Parade will process through town today at approximately 2:30 p.m. Hope to see many friends and alumni at the Homecoming football game tonight at 7 p.m. at BHHS's Elmer Bankus Field.

On Wednesday night, the "Powder Puff" football event (where teams of girls from each grade competed in flag football) raised $500 for Katelyn's Cause! The sophomores prevailed.

Also: An upcoming "Powder Tuff" event is planned on Nov. 1 at 7 p.m. in the high school gym (where the boys will play volleyball). Admission will be donations only and will once again go to Katelyn's Cause. This local nonprofit helps local families in medical emergencies. They provide families traveling to Doernbecher Children's Hospital in Portland with gas cards and other needs that they may have because a child is having medical tests or procedures.

#gobruins #happyhomecoming #bruinpride

On Wednesday night, the "Powder Puff" football event (where teams of girls from each grade competed in flag football) raised $500 for Katelyn's Cause! The sophomores prevailed.

Also: An upcoming "Powder Tuff" event is planned on Nov. 1 at 7 p.m. in the high school gym (where the boys will play volleyball). Admission will be donations only and will once again go to Katelyn's Cause. This local nonprofit helps local families in medical emergencies. They provide families traveling to Doernbecher Children's Hospital in Portland with gas cards and other needs that they may have because a child is having medical tests or procedures.

#gobruins #happyhomecoming #bruinpride

post_text:
Reminder: Nationwide emergency text alert test planned for Wednesday, Oct. 3, during school hours 11:18 am PDT.

---

Did you know? The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), in coordination with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), will conduct a nationwide test of the Emergency Alert System (EAS) and Wireless Emergency Alerts (WEA) on Oct. 3, 2018. The WEA portion of the test commences at 2:18 p.m. EDT, and the EAS portion follows at 2:20 p.m. EDT. The test will assess the operational readiness of the infrastructure for distribution of a national message and determine whether improvements are needed.
The WEA test message will be sent to cell phones that are connected to wireless providers participating in WEA. This is the fourth EAS nationwide test and the first national WEA test. Previous EAS national tests were conducted in November 2011, September 2016, and September 2017 in collaboration with the FCC, broadcasters, and emergency management officials in recognition of FEMA’s National Preparedness Month.

The EAS is a national public warning system that provides the President with the communications capability to address the nation during a national emergency. The test is made available to EAS participants (i.e., radio and television broadcasters, cable systems, satellite radio and television providers, and wireline video providers) and is scheduled to last approximately one minute. The test message will be similar to regular monthly EAS test messages with which the public is familiar. The EAS message will include a reference to the WEA test:

“THIS IS A TEST of the National Emergency Alert System. This system was developed by broadcast and cable operators in voluntary cooperation with the Federal Emergency Management Agency, the Federal Communications Commission, and local authorities to keep you informed in the event of an emergency. If this had been an actual emergency an official message would have followed the tone alert you heard at the start of this message. A similar wireless emergency alert test message has been sent to all cell phones nationwide. Some cell phones will receive the message; others will not. No action is required.”

Cell towers will broadcast the WEA test for approximately 30 minutes beginning at 2:18 p.m. EDT. During this time, WEA compatible cell phones that are switched on, within range of an active cell tower, and whose wireless provider participates in WEA should be capable of receiving the test message. Some cell phones will not receive the test message, and cell phones should only receive the message once. The WEA test message will have a header that reads "Presidential Alert" and text that says:

“THIS IS A TEST of the National Wireless Emergency Alert System. No action is needed.”

The WEA system is used to warn the public about dangerous weather, missing children, and other critical situations through alerts on cell phones. The national test will use the same special tone and vibration as with all WEA messages (i.e. Tornado Warning, AMBER Alert). Users cannot opt out of receiving the WEA test.

The test was originally planned for Sept. 20, 2018 but has been postponed until Oct. 3, 2018 due to ongoing response efforts to Hurricane Florence.

post_text:
Battle of the Books is off to a great start with about 85-90 students from the elementary, 38 from the middle school and a group of students for the first time in our district at the high school. About 13 students are giving it a try in grades 9-12 grade division.

Kalmiopsis Elementary will have an after-school class for participants starting this week: Every Wednesday, 2:25-3:10 p.m. through January.

Azalea Middle School will have a before-school class for participants will be every Tuesday morning fro 7:40-8:10 a.m., beginning Tuesday, October 9.

High school practices times are TBA. For now, they are tentatively at lunchtimes on Wednesdays, beginning this week.

Looking forward to a great year of OBOB competition!

If you have questions, contact District Librarian Patricia Clark.

shared_text:
Brookings-Harbor School District 17C
September 17, 2018 at 10:24 AM ·

Brookings-Harbor School District 17C school board has a vacant position to fill.

Former board member Lonnie Nalls resigned his position last week. The remaining board members (Bruce Raleigh, Alan Nidiffer, Katherine Johnson, and Sue Gold) will appoint a volunteer board member ASAP to serve until the next election.

Applications for Appointment to Board of Directors Position 5 will be accepted by the Superintendent’s Office until 4 p.m. Wednesday, Oct. 10. The board appointee will hold this position until June 30, 2019.

A new board member will be elected in the May 2019 election for the remainder of the term (2 years), starting July 1, 2019. The appointed board member may file for candidacy in the election if they so choose. For more information on the process, see BHSD17 policies BBC and BBE in the Policy Book: http://policy.osba.org/brookings/

Application for Appointment to Board of Directors Position 5 [PDF]: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/cms_files/resources/Board%20Application%202018.pdf

What a turnout this morning for the Back-To-School Community Breakfast! At least 364 people shared a meal to welcome new teachers and staff, hear updates about district goals and initiatives from Superintendent Sean Gallagher, and celebrate our Brookings-Harbor students.

The school district received a whopping donation of school supplies and cash from the KURY 95.3 Community School Supply Drive. THANK YOU to all who donated. You are making a difference for our students and teachers by helping provide the tools needed to succeed.

The start of school may still be 10 days away, but the fall sports teams have been practicing hard and many of the Bruin squads have hosted or traveled to preseason competition this weekend. Here are some upcoming preseason/non-league varsity events:

- BHHS Football vs. the joint Pacific High School/Gold Beach High School team, 7 p.m. Friday, Aug. 31, at Gold Beach.

- BHHS Boys Soccer vs. Marshfield, 2 p.m. Tuesday, Aug. 28, at Marshfield High School, Coos Bay.

- BHHS Girls Soccer vs. Illinois Valley, 4:30 p.m. Wednesday, Aug. 29 at home.

- BHHS Volleyball vs. McKinleyville, 7 p.m. Wednesday, Aug. 29, at McKinleyville High School, McKinleyville, CA.

- BHHS Cross Country at the Annual Bill Springhorn Classic, Friday, Aug. 31, at Shasta College, Redding, CA.

Find fall practice and competition schedules for BHHS: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/highschool/athletics.cfm and http://www.osaa.org/schools/159

Find fall practice and competition schedules for AMS: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/middleschool/Athletics.cfm

Also: Meet the new BHHS athletic coordinator Jean Shearer: https://www.currypilot.com/sports/6472660-151/new-year-new-league-new-ad

--
The official details on the first day of school:
- Sept. 4 is the first day back for grades 1-5, 6, 9 and new students.
- Sept. 5 grades 7-8 and 10-12 join in.
- Sept. 7 kindergarten starts (students have individual appointments earlier in the week).
#everystudentcansucceed #gobruins #bruinpride #summercountdown #bruinbuilt #winnow #fpf

post_text:
Exciting news: Brookings Elementary School
designated ‘Monarch School USA’ site!

The City of Brookings was designated a “Monarch City USA” in May 2017, as the first city in Oregon to receive the distinction, and now Kalmiopsis Elementary School has been designated a “Monarch School USA” — one of just a handful across the country and only the second school in Oregon to receive the honor for its commitment to restoring critical habitat and forage for the conservation of monarch butterfly populations.

There will be a brief ceremony for the hanging of a “Monarch School USA” sign at 10 a.m. Thursday, Aug. 23, at the Little Bear Patch garden, at Kalmiopsis Elementary School, 650 Easy St. A celebratory potluck will follow, all are welcome.

The monarch butterfly is one of the most recognizable butterflies in North America and yet has faced declining numbers due to habitat loss and fragmentation throughout its massive migratory range. Brookings Oregon Monarch Advocates (BOMA) is a local group of concerned individuals engaged in all aspects of conservation of the monarch butterfly. BOMA aims to educate the general public regarding captive, responsible rearing of monarchs and growth of host plants for caterpillars and adults.

Recently the school district’s Youth Transition Program students partnered with BOMA to clean out 36 beds in the Little Bear Patch garden to establish a pollinator garden containing host plants such as milkweed for caterpillars; and nectar plants for adult butterflies, as well as bees and other pollinator species. Such gardens provide important way stations for monarchs.

It took a village: The YTP students and other students enrolled in classes with teacher Michelle Prudden were a big part of the renovation, along with BOMA volunteers, Stacia Ryder, Lynette McPherson, Maureen Leigh, and Wade Stumpenhaus. The Elkton Butterfly Sanctuary provided the school district with discounted nectar plants, Eco-Nutrients donated organic locally sourced fertilizer, South Coast Lumber Co. donated the lumber, and Gold Beach Lumber donated supplies as well. Curry County Master Gardners donated funding for soil that the district received at a discounted rate from Hambro in Crescent City.

Monarch City USA is a national nonprofit, based in Washington State, with the goal to inspire the nation's municipalities to become supporters of the monarch butterfly by planting milkweed and nectar plants throughout their areas. Brookings City Councilor Dennis Triglia, a BOMA volunteer, learned that Monarch City USA also had a Monarch School USA program, and inquired on behalf of the schools.

"It was very exciting when Monarch City USA received the membership application for Brookings and the K-School,” said Russell Stubbles, head of the Monarch City/School USA program. “We could now formally recognize the wonderful work being done by the local citizens, particularly BOMA, and the students. We have members in many states, but Brookings’ participation shows the nation that the efforts to save the monarch butterfly goes from the Pacific Ocean to the Atlantic Ocean.”

The Monarch City USA program currently has two sites in Florida, representing the East Coast. The only other school in Oregon with this Monarch School USA designation is Sisters Middle School in Sisters, Ore.

The BOMA volunteers have also participated with the school to raise monarch eggs and caterpillars to adult butterflies. After they emerge from their chrysalises and are ready for release, each butterfly is “tagged” with a small sticker containing a specific number for each butterfly and an email address for tracking their migration to overwintering sites in California. Releasing the full-grown butterflies has been a highlight of the year for several elementary classrooms.

“It is a citizen science effort and a wonderful educational tool in the STEM toolbox for the students,” Triglia said.

BOMA is planning a First Annual Monarch Festival from noon to 4 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 15, at Azalea Park in Brookings. The event aims to recruit and teach more citizen scientists to plan milkweed plants and how to raise and monitor monarchs.

For more information on Monarch City USA, see monarchcityusa.com.

post_text:
Extended School Day - Get the Facts!

WHO: Open to all high school students.

WHAT: At Brookings-Harbor High School we are committed to providing your child with all the tools we can to help them be successful in their high school career. Extended School Day is a service that we offer to ensure that your student has all the access to materials, tools, and assistance they need to not only meet their classroom requirements but exceed them. We provide:
- Adult and peer tutors to work one on one with your child to get them the help they need.
- Snacks provided by the local Brookings Harbor Community Helpers Emergency Food Bank to ensure they have the energy to put their minds to work.
- Adult assistance to help them navigate the complex world of managing multiple deadlines.
- Bus service at 4:30 p.m. to bring your child home.

WHEN: From 3:30 to 4:30 p.m. every Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday on regular school days. Our coordinator is also available every block day from 8 a.m. to 8:20 a.m. and during office hours. Additional times can be arranged to fit you and your child's schedule.

WHERE: Brookings-Harbor High School Library.

CONTACT: If you would like more information or have any questions, please feel free to contact the program coordinator Gretchen Francisco by email at gretchenf@brookings.k12.or.us or by phone at 541-469-2108 ext. 4016.

Psst ... only 19 days to go. #everystudentcansucceed #gobruins #bruinpride #summercountdown

post_text:
Have you heard of the TRiO Talent Search program? SWOCC's Educational Talent Search program, TRiO is accepting new applications for Coos and Curry middle and high school students in grades 6-10 who want to prepare for life after high school. The program helps students stay in school, explore careers, trades and colleges and offers fun learning opportunities. All events are free.

Students can sign up at registration today, or ANYTIME in the BHHS Guidance & Counseling Bruin Center.

Brookings-Harbor High School TRiO students can participate in the many great trips planned this year:
- Pacific Northwest College Fair and tour of Southern Oregon University (October)
- Tour Oregon State University and Linn-Benton Community College (November)
- College 101 for Juniors at Southwestern, Umpqua Community College and Rogue Community College tours, Humboldt University tour (January)
- Freshman experience conference, Engineering and Natural Resources careers dinners, Tech Trek and tour of Oregon Institute of Technology (February)
-Criminal Justice Careers Day and tour of Western Oregon University (March)
-Sophomore Success Conference (April)
-Oregon Institute of Marine Biology in Charleston (May)

Plus special trips for new members include a Jerry's Rogue Jets boat trip to Cougar Lane on August 29 and bowling with other freshman and sophomores in Coos Bay! (Must sign-up by Aug. 22 to participate in new member trips).

For more information visit www.socc.edu/ts/ Southwestern Oregon Community College and SOUTHWESTERN Oregon Community College Curry Campus.

---
The summer countdown is starting to get real. We hope you are enjoying August and as excited about the new school year as we are! ... 20 days to go until Sept. 4 (first day back for grades 1-5, 6, 9 and new students). Grades 7-8 and 10-12 start Sept. 5. Kindergarten starts Sept. 7.

#everystudentcansucceed #gobruins #bruinpride #summercountdown

Today was a great first day of on-site registration. Remaining students and family members, please come for the second and final day TOMORROW (Thursday, Aug. 16) between noon and 6 p.m. at Kalmiopsis Elementary to complete your registration activities, learn about school programs and take care of items such as athletics/activities fees and PE uniforms.

Also: The bell/bus schedules and September breakfast and lunch menus are all UPDATED for 2018-19 on the school district and individual school websites. Please note that the school day is slightly longer than previous years as part of a long-term plan to increase instructional time for the academic success of our students, and there are now two early release Tuesdays most months. Bus, bell, lunch and recess schedules have shifted accordingly.

Get the details here: https://www.brookings.k12.or.us/bell-and-bus-schedules.cfm

post_text:
Did you know? Kalmiopsis Elementary was recently approved to participate in the Provision 2 National School Lunch and School Breakfast Program. This means that this school year we will be serving not only breakfast but lunch FREE to all Kalmiopsis students.

In order for the district to complete this process to make the most for this exciting program, WE NEED YOUR HELP. We are asking all head of households to fill out a Free or Reduced application regardless of income in the household. By doing this it will help provide the most funding we can get as far as providing the free meals to your children(s) over the next several years.

There are two ways to fill out the "free and reduced application":

1. Go to www.brookings.k12.or.us. On the right-hand side of webpage, you will find a box that says "Online Payments." Set up your account. Once registered, go to the online application box. In order to complete the application you will need your child(rens) school lunch I.D. number. Once complete, please submit. We highly suggest filling out the online application.

2. Fill-out a paper form. You can find paper forms at any one of the front offices at any of the BHSD schools.

Regardless if your child(ren) participate in the free breakfast and lunch program, we need ALL households to fill out the application. Provision 2 only requires this process once every four years, so for the next three years no applications will be collected, and the free breakfast and lunch program will continue at Kalmiopsis.

Pssst... We passed 25 days until the first day of school on Friday (sorry for the late post). The first day of school for Grades 1-5, 6 and 9 and any other new students to the middle school or high school is Tuesday, Sept. 4. The first day of school for grades 7-8 and 10-12 is Wednesday, Sept. 5, when they will join the students that have already started. Kindergartener families will be contacted for scheduling an introductory visit during the first week, with regular classes starting at the end of the week on Friday, Sept. 7.

#everystudentcansucceed #gobruins #bruinpride #summercountdown

Curry Community Health’s School Based Health Center has moved locations during the summer months and is now located at 629 Easy Street (in the modular building in the parking lot of Brookings-Harbor High School).

The BHHS School Based Health Center is a medical clinic that offers children and youth health care at school or on school grounds. The SBHC has a Public Health Nurse, a Family Nurse Practitioner, and a Mental Health Therapist. Service hours: Monday-Thursday (Closed Fridays) 8:30am-12pm, 1pm-5pm. Phone: 541-251-7076.

shared_text:
OHS.ORG
The Remembrance of World War II

Brookings-Harbor High School
August 3, 2018 at 12:14 PM ·

Great news! The Oregon Historical Society in Portland has EXTENDED the BHHS WWII exhibit until Aug. 16!

Details: The work of Brookings-Harbor High School students is on display at the Oregon Historical Society in Portland this summer. The exhibit “In Remembrance of WWII” created by BHHS history classes features the stories, photographs, and artifacts of local Curry County veterans. The project was originally displayed during Azalea Days and at the 2018 BHHS Student Achievement Night. It was a big honor when the OCF learned about it and put it on display from July 26-28 in Portland. According to the OCF staff, people have been gathering around it telling their stories and sharing memories. Due to its popularity, the OCF has extended the exhibit until Aug. 16! Ms. Kelly Garvin and her students thank the community for its support of this project. Learn more on the OHS website: http://www.ohs.org/museum/exhibits/the-remembrance-of-world-war-ii.cfm

post_text:
The end of July and start of August marks 35 days left before the first day of school!

Did you know that the Brookings-Harbor School District has added propane-powered buses to its fleet in recent years? The district currently has 3 buses that are powered by propane, and a fourth arriving this summer. Propane is a promising alternative fuel for school buses because it is widely available, even in rural areas, and it can cost less than diesel or gasoline. In a recent study, some school districts save nearly 50% on a cost per mile basis for fuel and maintenance relative to diesel. Propane buses are also quiet and create a lower amount of carbon emissions.
(Source: https://www.afdc.energy.gov/uploads/publication/case-study-propane-school-bus-fleets.pdf)

Also: We are hiring! Applications are open for Substitute Bus Drivers at this time. Information: https://www.applitrack.com/brookings/onlineapp/default.aspx?all=1

#everystudentcansucceed #gobruins #bruinpride #summercountdown

FYI: Tolowa Youth Language Camp registrations are due this Friday!

Dee-dvn-la: Wednesday, August 15th - Friday, August 17th Dvt-la: Meet at Xaa-wan'-k'wvt Village Resort
Ghvt-ti~lh: Arrive at 8 am. Return at 5 pm

The Waa-tr'vslh-'a~ Department & Dee-ni' Wee-ya' Committee invites youth to participate in our upcoming 13th Annual Dee-ni' Mvsr-xee-ye' Wee-ya' Lhetlh-xat on August 15th-17th, for ages 7-13 years old; children under the age of 7 years are welcome when accompanied by an adult. This year we will be a day camp as we will be visiting different sites giving our youth an opportunity to experience different culturally significant sites. Friday will be spent at Shaa-xu'-xat (Rowdy Creek). Please complete the registration form and return it to the Sri'-swrvlh Mee-ne' Building or the K'vs-chu Tribal Office no later than Friday, July 27th, 2018 @ 5:00 PM. Call Amber for more info 707.487.3236

Did you know?

The work of Brookings-Harbor High School students is on display at the Oregon Historical Society in Portland this summer. The WWII exhibit featuring the stories, photographs, and artifacts of local Curry County veterans will be on display from July 26-28. Students will be there on hand at 1 pm July 28 to take questions. Ms. Kelly Garvin and her history students thank the community for its support of this project.

Learn more: http://www.ohs.org/museum/exhibits/the-remembrance-of-world-war-ii.cfm

One year ago this week, the Chetco Bar Fire started deep in the Kalmiopsis Wilderness. It went on to become a major fire incident bringing many challenges and changes for our community and schools. Brookings-Harbor School District Supt. Sean Gallagher shared the experience in the Oregon Small Schools Association "Small Talk" summer newsletter with "5 Lessons Learned When Wildfire Raced Toward Our Schools." Check it out here: https://v3.boardbook.org/Public/PublicItemDownload.aspx?ik=42761817

---

Psst. 50 Days Until School! We will be sharing the 2018-19 School Supply lists and information about the Stuff the Bus annual community school supply drive soon. If you'd like to look at last year's list to get an idea, you can access them here:

- Azalea Middle School supply lists: http://www.brookings.k12.or.us/middleschool/School%20Supply%20List.pdf

post_text:
Have a child entering school this fall?

Starting Kindergarten isn't just learning letters and numbers. It's important that you help practice independent tasks with your child ahead of time. Here are some ideas for places to start. It's OK to make a game out of it and give them lots of encouragement.

- Going to the bathroom (unbuttoning and fastening pants)
- Dressing (changing clothes, zipping coats, and fastening shoes)
- Eating lunch (opening juice boxes)
- Separating from parents
- Knowing full-name and phone number
- Following two-step directions

(Source: http://www.readbrightly.com/10-things-can-summer-get-child-ready-kindergarten/)

#everystudentcansucceed #gobruins #bruinpride #summercountdown

post_text:
Been wondering what’s happening behind that temporary green construction fencing at Azalea Middle School?
The middle school is undergoing an extensive seismic safety retrofit this summer! The retrofit work includes checking existing structure strength and flexibility and checking for hazards. That includes reinforcing building infrastructure, removing some large windows throughout the buildings, re-supporting heavy HVAC units and other large items, and making sure that brickwork is tied into the walls correctly. The update will ensure that everything from the roof to the foundation is connected properly to provide safe passage for evacuation and to help prevent a major collapse in the event of an earthquake.
Because this work requires the opening of most of the walls and ceilings in the school, students will return to new fresh paint and new fixtures, such as improved lighting, ventilation systems and even new showers in the locker room!
Last summer (2017) Kalmiopsis Elementary received safety updates, and next summer (2019) the plan is to complete a similar project at Brookings-Harbor High School. All told, the school district has received about $4.5 million in grants from Business Oregon for the safety projects. The program provides funding for construction work on schools and other critical public buildings to better prepare the structures to withstand a major earthquake, and to ensure that safe community gathering places are available for emergency response.
Project management on behalf of the district is provided by Darryl Anderson of Anderson Engineering and Surveying, all design engineering and construction is in partnership with Ausland Group of Grants Pass, in addition, multiple local subcontractors have been hired for the project.

#everystudentcansucceed #gobruins #bruinpride #summercountdown

post_text:
Did you know? Both Kalmiopsis Elementary and Brookings Head Start have SMART reading programs. Last year, these programs served 106 children by providing one-on-one reading support from trained community volunteers. Participating children received a new book each moth to keep. Last year at Kalmiopsis, 944 new, quality books were chosen by participating students to keep! Thank you to the community volunteers that help make this program possible! SMART is looking for volunteers for the 2018-19 school year. If you are interested, please contact Cheryl Brown, South Coast Area Manager, SMART (Start Making A Reader Today) at cbrown@getsmartoregon.org. Visit the website at getsmartoregon.org or Facebook page at www.facebook.com/StartMakingAReaderToday

While celebrating the end of the 2017-18 school year, the teachers and staff of Brookings-Harbor School District came together for a BBQ last Thursday to recognize the accomplishments of the past year; and to give well wishes to team members departing for retirement, new jobs, and other new adventures. This year, we said farewell to these “Forever” Bruins:

District Office:
- Kathy McKee (Director of Fiscal Services)

Brookings-Harbor High School:
- Alex Merritt (Vice Principal)
- Greg Goode (Music Teacher)
- Joe Morin (Digital Arts/CTE Instructor)

Azalea Middle School:
- Nancy Chew (Social Studies Teacher)
- Lisa Wendel (Language Arts Teacher)
- Rebecca Farmer (Life Skills Teacher)

Kalmiopsis Elementary School:
- Krista Connelly (Vice Principal)
- Deb Dorn (Special Education Teacher)
- Briana Rucker (Indian Education Assistant)
- Vikki Pruden (Second Grade Teacher)
- Sherry Friar (Instructional Assistant)
- Gina June (Kindergarten Teacher)
- Turi Lundquist (Third Grade Teacher)

At the celebration, we also recognized veterans of the district with “Years of Service” pins.

5 Years of Service to BHSD17C:
- Jessica Alexander
- Cindy Badger
- Jess Beaman
- Matt Bennett
- Krista Connelly
- Darcie Gutierrez
- Mike McQueen
- Nicole Medrano
- Christal Miller
- Dane Tippman
- Kristi Weese
- Christine Zellmer

10 Years of Service to BHSD17C:
- Brenda Robbins

15 Years of Service to BHSD17C:
- Nancy Chew

20 Years of Service to BHSD17C:
- Cheryl Buehler
- Kathy McKee
- Sarah Sackett

25 Years of Service to BHSD17C:
-Sherry Friar
- Kristi Fulton
- Perry Kleespies

30 Years of Services to BHSD17C:
- Vikki Pruden

Thank you, teachers and staff, for all you do to make sure that “Every Student Can Succeed.” Have a great summer!

Photo: Cheryl Buehler and Kathy McKee were among those thanked for 20 Years of Service to the School District on Thursday.

Today is the last day of school!

REMINDER: Summer Food Program Starts June 18

The Brookings-Harbor School District Summer Food Program will run Monday through Thursday, June 18-July 26, 2018, at the Brookings-Harbor High School Cafeteria, 625 Pioneer Road.

Breakfast will be served from 8 a.m. to 8:45 a.m.and lunch will be served from 11:45 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. Monday through Thursday, except for the Independence Day holiday on July 4.

The summer food service program provides free healthy meals to children ages 18 and younger AT NO COST! Parents/guardians are welcomed to join too! (Adult meals cost $2.50 for breakfast and $3.75 for lunch).

Fresh food from the school district gardens is included in the salad bar when available.

Psst ... We sent out dozens, but have a few large format posters left like the ones posted here. It you have a business, church or other location in town that would like to have one, post a comment below or message this page.

shared_text:
Brookings-Harbor High School
June 10, 2018 at 1:38 AM ·

Here's a quick recap of today's graduation celebration. What a great day for the Bruin community. Congratulations, graduates, families and friends!

#gobruins #bruinpride #everystudentcansucceed #GRADitude

Brookings-Harbor High School celebrated the achievement of 108 new graduates at the annual ceremony Saturday, June 9, at Elmer Bankus Field.

At the ceremony, Principal Lisa Dion, Superintendent Sean Gallagher, and school board members made the presentations for honors for academic excellence. This year's Valedictorians was Mia Adams and Emma Leonard. Salutatorian was Savannah Goetze.

For the second year in a row, the senior class students selected economics and American government and policy teacher Gregory Scott as "Teacher of the Year." Principal Lisa Dion and Vice Principal Alex Merritt gave the keynote address.

Senior Class President Abby Farmer read the roll call of students receiving diplomas. To see the full list of this year's graduates and honors, visit www.brookings.k12.or.us.

The Class of 2018 is projected to earn the highest graduation rate for the Bruins in a decade, likely to break into the 80th percentile.
text:
Brookings-Harbor High School
June 10, 2018 at 1:38 AM ·

Here's a quick recap of today's graduation celebration. What a great day for the Bruin community. Congratulations, graduates, families and friends!

#gobruins #bruinpride #everystudentcansucceed #GRADitude

Brookings-Harbor High School celebrated the achievement of 108 new graduates at the annual ceremony Saturday, June 9, at Elmer Bankus Field.

At the ceremony, Principal Lisa Dion, Superintendent Sean Gallagher, and school board members made the presentations for honors for academic excellence. This year's Valedictorians was Mia Adams and Emma Leonard. Salutatorian was Savannah Goetze.

For the second year in a row, the senior class students selected economics and American government and policy teacher Gregory Scott as "Teacher of the Year." Principal Lisa Dion and Vice Principal Alex Merritt gave the keynote address.

Senior Class President Abby Farmer read the roll call of students receiving diplomas. To see the full list of this year's graduates and honors, visit www.brookings.k12.or.us.

The Class of 2018 is projected to earn the highest graduation rate for the Bruins in a decade, likely to break into the 80th percentile.
